questions.text: Which of the following MRI imaging techniques is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The MRI shows CSF as bright/hyperintense while white matter is dark and grey matter is white, hence this is a T2 weighted MRI image. 

T1 weighted image

  • It is one of the basic MRI pulse sequences.
  • The difference in the appearance of various tissues is due to their different T1 relaxation times.
  • CSF has a long T1 time and appears dark.

T2 weighted images:

  • It is also a basic MRI pulse sequence.
  • It is based on the T2 relaxation time of the tissues.
  • CSF appears bright in these images.

 

Short tau inversion recovery(STIR):

  • It is a form of inversion recovery sequence.
  • It is used to selectively null signals from fat.
  • The imaging sequence is identified by observing the fat tissues and fluid-filled spaces.
  • Fluids like CSF appear bright and fat appears dark.

 

Fluid attenuated inversion recovery(FLAIR):

  • It is also a form of inversion recovery sequence.
  • It is used to selectively null signals from fluids.
  • Fluids like CSF appear dark and pathological processes appear bright.
  • It would appear as a fluid suppressed T2 image.

Related Pearl: T1 vs T2 MRI

questions.text: Identify the instrument used in thyroid surgery, shown below.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image above is Joll retractor. Joll retractor is a self-retaining retractor used in thyroid surgery.

Travers retractor is a self-retaining retractor used for herniorrhaphy, groin dissection for varicose veins, and femoral embolectomy.

Travers Retractor:

Dyball retractor is used in major abdominal surgeries:

Spencer Wells is a ratchet type forceps used extensively in surgery to clamp the artery before cutting it:

questions.text: Investigation of choice for acute pancreatitis is_______
questions.solution:
• Contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice.
  • The optimal time for performing CECT is more than 72 h after the onset of symptoms (In the first 72 hours, CT may underestimate the extent of necrosis).

Acute pancreatitis is a condition characterized by inflammatory damage to the pancreas. Various causes of acute pancreatitis are:

  • Gall stone induced (most common cause)
  • Alcohol (2nd most common cause)
  • Trauma (most common cause in children)
  • Iatrogenic- Post endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
  • Drug-induced pancreatitis (Thiazides, Azathioprine, Anti-cancer drugs, etc)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Scorpion bite
  • Idiopathic

Clinical presentation of acute pancreatitis is characterized by epigastric pain radiating to the back which is relieved by bending forward, nausea, and vomiting. Acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis can present with certain named signs like:

  • Cullen’s sign: Discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Grey Turner’s sign: Discoloration in the flanks
  • Fox sign: Discoloration in the inguinal region
  • Bryant’s sign: Discoloration on the scrotum

Blood investigations show increased serum amylase and lipase levels. Serum lipase is more sensitive and specific than serum amylase but it rises late. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) is the investigation of choice. Various scoring systems are used to grade the severity of acute pancreatitis based on blood investigations and radiographic findings.

The severity of pancreatitis detected on CT is staged according to the Balthazar criteria.

Related Pearl: Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI)/Balthazar Scoring for Acute Pancreatitis

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman who is a known smoker presents with slit-like retraction of the right nipple. She gives a history of chronic greenish discharge from the same site previously. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of chronic greenish discharge followed by slit-like retraction of the nipple in a middle-aged woman is suggestive of duct ectasia.

Duct ectasia is the dilatation of major breast ducts. It is a common cause of nipple discharge in non-lactating women. This disease's initial stage consists of dilating one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts fill with stagnant brown or green-coloured secretions, and discharge from the collection may occur.

In the later stages, fluid accumulation in the lactiferous ducts leads to inflammation causing periductal mastitis. If the condition does not resolve, it can lead to the formation of a subareolar mass or abscess, and even mammary duct fistulas. The persistence of this condition eventually leads to fibrosis, which can cause slit-like retraction of the nipple.

Initial episodes can be managed with antibiotics. Recurrent episodes of the disease are best managed by Hadfield operation. This operation consists of the excision of all the major lactiferous ducts.  If a single duct is involved, then a microdochectomy is performed.

The mammography image of broken-needle calcification seen in duct ectasia is seen below.

Other options:

Option A: Intraductal papilloma is a benign condition wherein a wart-like growth occurs within the mammary ducts. They are made up of glandular and fibrous tissue and vascular vessels. It is associated with blood-stained discharge.

Option C: Fibroadenoma presents as a breast lump in women aged 15–25 years. The ultrasound image depicts a well-circumscribed oval mass with uniform hypoechogenicity as given in the image below.

Option D: Paget’s disease is a type of in-situ carcinoma arising in the nipple characterized by nipple erythema and irritation. It is associated with pruritus and slowly destroys the nipple and the areola. The image below shows Paget's disease of the breast.

questions.text: Sentinel lymph node procedure is most useful in which of the following gynecological malignancy?
questions.solution:
Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful in vulval carcinoma among gynecological malignancies.

Restricting unnecessary lymph node dissection reduces the surgical morbidity in early vulval cancer. However, to do this, determination of the extent of primary lymph node (sentinel) involvement is necessary. Lymphatic mapping and sentinel node biopsy (frozen section) before or during surgery help in carrying out adequate surgical procedure with good prognosis.

Mapping is done by:

-Intraoperative intradermal injection of blue dye around the tumour. A detection rate of 100% is reported.

-Labelling tissues with radioactive tracer and localization with a hand-held detector.

-Lymphoscintigraphy has also 100% detection rate.

Other malignancies where Sentinel lymph node biopsy is commonly done are :

  • Breast carcinoma
  • Penile carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma

This question was asked in AIIMS examination in recent years, making it potential repeat in future examinations.

Related Pearl: Staging of Vulval Cancer (FIGO)

Stage Features
I Tumor confined to vulva
IA Lesions ≤2 cm in size, confined to the vulva or perineum and with stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm, no nodal metastasis
IB Lesions >2cm in size or with stromal invasion >1mm , confined to the vulva or perineum, with negative nodes
II Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with negative nodes
III Tumor of any size with/without extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, anus) with positive inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IIIA i) With 1 lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm) or,
  ii)1-2 lymph node micrometastases(<5mm)
IIIB i) With 2 or more lymph node macrometastases (≥5mm), or
  ii) 3 or more lymph node micrometastases (<5 mm)
IIIC With positive nodes with extracapsular spread
IV Tumor invades other regional structures (upper 2/3rd urethra, upper 2/3rd vagina) or distant structures
IVA Tumour invades any of the following:
  i) Upper urethral and/or vaginal mucosa, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to the pelvic bone, or
  ii) Fixed or ulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes
IVB Any distant metastasis including pelvic lymph nodes

questions.text: Identify the given image based on the Doppler findings.
questions.solution:
The umbilical artery Doppler depicts the reversal of end-diastolic flow (waves appearing below the baseline) which is seen in intrauterine growth restriction. 

Abnormal flow patterns in the umbilical artery:

Reduced End diastolic flow: Uteroplacental insufficiency (S/D ratio increases)

Absent End diastolic flow: Fetal compromise - terminate the pregnancy by cesarean section if >34 weeks.

Reverse end diastolic flow: Impending doom of death - terminate pregnancy irrespective of gestational age.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with Parkinsonism and cerebellar features. MRI showed the “hot cross buns” sign. He is most likely to have ________
questions.solution:
Parkinsonism, cerebellar features, and "hot cross bun" sign on MRI suggest multiple system atrophy (MSA).

MSA manifests as a combination of parkinsonian, cerebellar, and autonomic features. Based on predominant clinical features it is further divided into :

  • MSA-P: predominantly parkinsonian features
  • MSA-C: predominantly cerebellar features

Characteristic MRI findings include:

  • MSA-P:T2 weighted imaging demonstrates hyperintense putaminal rim 
  • MSA-C: cerebellar and brainstem atrophy causing pontine hot cross bun sign

Image: MRI showing pontine hot cross bun sign in MSA-C.

questions.text:
You see the senior resident ordering the following medications for a patient with end-stage kidney disease. What is the electrolyte abnormality that he is trying to correct?
  1. Intravenous calcium gluconate 
  2. Regular insulin with dextrose 
  3. Salbutamol nebulization
questions.solution:
The most likely electrolyte abnormality that is being corrected using the above is hyperkalemia.

Hyperkalemia is defined as a serum potassium level of more than 5.5 mEq/L. It can cause drastic conduction changes. It can be diagnosed by a sequence of changes affecting the ST-T segments and QRS complex. ST-T segment changes reflect a change in repolarization, while QRS complex changes reflect a change in depolarization.

The ECG changes that can be seen in hyperkalemia depend on the extent of hyperkalemia. 

S. No. Serum potassium level ECG change
1 5.5–6.5 mEq/L Tall, peaked T waves with 'tented' or 'pinched' shape
2 6.5–7.5 mEq/L Loss of P waves
3 7.0–8.0 mEq/L Widened QRS complex
4 > 8.0 mEq/L Sine wave

Drugs that cause hyperkalemia include the following:

  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers, e.g. losartan 
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor blockers like spirinolactone, eplerenone, and drospirenone
  • Epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) blockers like amiloride, triamterene, trimethoprim, pentamidine, and nafamostat

The most common cause of hyperkalemia is kidney failure. 

Treatment of hyperkalemia involves the following:

  1. Administer intravenous calcium gluconate, which raises the threshold and reduces excitability. It is cardioprotective.
  2. Administer regular insulin with dextrose. The insulin will reduce the serum potassium concentration by causing an intracellular shift. The dextrose will counteract the hypoglycemic effects of insulin.
  3. Provide salbutamol nebulization, which will also shift potassium inside the cell.
  4. Remove potassium with calcium-based resins, diuretics, or hemodialysis.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old teacher presented for an annual checkup. On examination, prominent tortuous, dilated subcutaneous veins are present on the medial side of her lower leg with the CEAP classification C2a Ep As Pn. She is aware of her varicose veins and is asymptomatic. What is the next step in management?

CEAP - Clinical - Etiology - Anatomy - Pathophysiology classification of varicose veins
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of mild asymptomatic varicose veins according to the CEAP classification. Therefore, the next step in management is compression stockings.

In addition, she has no venous complications like pigmentation, eczema, or venous ulcers. Thus, she can be initially managed with compression stockings. 

Compression stockings provide external pressure to the limb which compresses the veins and improves venous return. There are two lengths available - knee or thigh length. However, knee-length stockings are commonly prescribed as they have better compliance. 

They are useful for the initial management of varicose veins as they relieve symptoms and are a conservative approach. If the varicose veins become symptomatic or become visually distressing then non-conservative approaches described below can be considered. 

Other options: 

Option A: Radiofrequency ablation uses electromagnetic currents to destroy the vein without damaging the other structures. It can only treat junctional and truncal incompetence and not varicosities. 

Option B: Saphenopopliteal ligation is a surgical procedure where the saphenopopliteal junction is dissected with flush ligation. Alternatively, the small saphenous vein can also be ligated as proximally as possible. Sural nerve neuropraxia and common peroneal nerve injury are possible complications. 

Option C: Saphenofemoral ligation is a surgical procedure made where the great saphenous vein is ligated and stripped. There are complications associated with this procedure such as saphenous nerve injury and neovascularization due to trauma leading to reoccurrence. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

C1

*The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.

Telangiectases are less than 1 mm, reticular veins are between 1 and 3 mm, and varicose veins are greater than 3 mm measured in the upright position.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy presented with weakness, fatigue, excessive thirst, and urination. His blood pressure was 100/76 mmHg. His lab parameters are given below. What is the diagnosis?

Urine transtubular potassium gradient (TTKG) - 8 (increased)

Urine calcium- increased

ABG analysis - metabolic alkalosis

Serum potassium - decreased (3.2 mmol/L)

Serum magnesium - decreased (0.3 mmol/L)
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of the diagnosis of Bartter syndrome.

Bartter syndrome is characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypomagnesemia (normal - 0.5 to 1 mmol/kg) and hypercalciuria with normal blood pressure. The transtubular potassium gradient (TTKG) is a physiologically based clinical test to study the renal excretion of potassium. A TTKG >4 in a patient with hypokalemia suggests excessive urinary losses of K+. 

Bartter syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to defects in various genes involved in the regulated Na+, K+, and Cl– transport by the thick ascending loop of Henle (TALH). Each genetic defect is a subtype of Bartter syndrome. Type 3 Bartter, also known as classical Bartter is due to loss of function in CLCKNB (Chloride Voltage-Gated Channel Kb).

A defect in the Na+/K+/Cl- channel impairs the transport functions of the TALH resulting in the following features:

  • Polyuria and polydipsia
  • Marked activation of RAAS leading to increased renal loss of potassium
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis due to bicarbonate retention
  • Hypomagnesemia in 20% of patients
  • Hypocalcemia and hypercalciuria
  • Normotensive

Antenal presentation of Bartter syndrome is characterized by polyhydramnios, premature birth, polyuria, and salt loss. Antenatal diagnosis can be made by elevated levels of chloride and aldosterone in the amniotic fluid. Antenatal Bartter can be managed by intravenous saline infusion to prevent dehydration and even death. Cyclooxygenase inhibitors are also useful in antenatal Bartter to reduce polyuria and salt wasting.

Other options:

Option A- Gitelman syndrome is due to a loss of function mutation in the thiazide sensitive Na+-Cl– cotransporter of the Distal convoluted tubule. It is characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypomagnesemia and hypocalciuria with normal blood pressure.

Option B: EAST syndrome is characterized by epilepsy, ataxia, sensorineural deafness, and tubulopathy. Biochemical abnormality is similar to Gitelman syndrome.

Option D: Liddle syndrome is due to direct increased activation of the epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) on the principal cells. Liddle's also causes hypokalemia, hypercalciuria but is characterized by severe hypertension.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: A mother of five, brings her youngest child, an 18-month-old girl, for evaluation. The child appears very thin with minimal fat distribution. There is severe wasting of the shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs as shown in the below image. The middle-upper arm circumference is less than 11.5cm. The child is alert and irritable. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The alert and irritable child with severe fat wasting in the areas of the shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs is likely to have marasmus. 

Marasmus is a type of severe protein-energy malnutrition which occurs due to insufficient calorie intake. It is characterized by severe wasting of fat and muscles. The child appears to be very thin,  having a 'skin and bones' appearance with no fat. 

The loss of buccal fat leads to the 'monkey facies' or 'old man face' due to its aged and wrinkled appearance. 'Baggy pants appearance' is due to the presence of loose skin in the buttocks that hangs low. 

Other features that may be present are hypotension, hypothermia, and bradycardia as well as micronutrient deficiencies. 

Diagnosis of severe acute malnutrition is made with the help of anthropometry.

  • Weight for height is below -3 standard deviations for the mean on the World Health Organization (WHO) chart  or,
  • Presence of bipedal edema or,
  • Middle-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is less than 115mm (in the red zone of the tape as shown below). 

 

The children should be assessed for the following: 

  • Severe edema 
  • Low appetite (failed appetite test) 
  • Medical complications 
  • One or more danger sign

If any of the above are present, the child should be treated as a case of complicated severe acute malnutrition and should have inpatient management. Uncomplicated cases can have supervised home management. 

The WHO recommends testing hemoglobin, total blood count, peripheral blood smear, blood glucose, serum albumin, electrolytes, stool microscopy with culture, parasitic evaluation, retroviral testing, and urine microscopy with culture. 

Other options: 

Option A - Kwashiorkor is another type of protein-energy malnutrition that is characterized mainly by pitting edema starting in the legs and feet that spread to the hands and face. They also show skin changes characterized by increased pigmentation and desquamation. They do not show signs of hunger and are difficult to feed. The weight for height may be normal. The following image shows the edema and the skin changes seen in Kwashiorkor.

 

Option C - Chronic pancreatitis can mimic protein-energy malnutrition. It can occur due to cystic fibrosis and obstruction of the pancreatic ducts due to roundworms. This would present with prolonged abdominal pain, weight loss, and steatorrhea. 

Option D - Marasmic kwashiorkor is a mixed form of malnutrition that presents with features of both marasmus and kwashiorkor. There will be edema, and growth stunting with less severe hair and skin changes of kwashiorkor.

Related Pearl: Differences between Marasmus and Kwashiorkar

Marasmus Kwashiorkor

Seen in older children

(6 months to 3 years of age)
Total calorie deficit Protein deficit
No edema Edema is prominent

Voracious appetite

No apathy

Loss of appetite

Apathy
Severe muscle wasting Muscle wasting mild or absent
Prominent ribs Protuberant abdomen

No Fatty liver

No subcutaneous fat

Fatty liver

Subcutaneous fat preserved

Special features:

  1. Alert
  2. Loose wrinkled skin 
  3. Baggy pant appearance

Special features:

  1. Moon face
  2. Flaky paint dermatosis
  3. Flag sign

The image below shows Flag sign characterised by alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal pigmented areas on the hair strand.

 

The image below shows a child with an old wrinkled old man appearance.

 

The image highlights the differentiating clinical features between marasmus and kwashiorkor

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with persistent fever and productive cough for 6 weeks with night sweats and anemia. The following is his CXR. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described along with the chest X-ray image showing air-fluid level is suggestive of a lung abscess.

The patients usually present with complaints of fever, cough with sputum production, and chest pain. Patients with putrid lung abscesses may report foul-smelling sputum. Patients with chronic lung abscesses usually have a history of night sweats, fatigue, and anemia.

On physical examination:

  • Poor dentition/gingival disease
  • Amphoric and/or cavernous breath sounds on lung auscultation
  • Digital clubbing
  • The absence of a gag reflex

CXR features of lung abscess:

  • A lung cavity with an air-fluid level
  • The cavity wall is thick and irregular, and a surrounding pulmonary-infiltrate is often present
  • Computed tomography (CT) is more sensitive than chest radiography and is used to detect small cavities

The two x-ray images given below show thick-walled cavities with air-fluid levels on lateral and PA views respectively.

Other options:

Carcinoma Lung:

  • Carcinoma of the lung can also present with symptoms like persistent cough, fever, night sweats, and anemia, especially if it has advanced and caused complications like infection or bleeding.
  • However, the CXR would show a different pattern such as a solitary pulmonary nodule, mass lesion, or hilar enlargement.
  • It may also demonstrate signs of metastasis such as multiple nodules in the lungs or distant spread to other organs, which are not apparent in the provided CXR.

Emphysematous bullae:

  • Emphysematous bullae are large air spaces within the lung parenchyma that can occur due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or other lung conditions.
  • While emphysema can lead to symptoms like cough and occasionally fever if there's a concurrent infection, it typically does not present with prolonged fever, night sweats, and anemia as prominent features. Additionally, the CXR shows consolidation rather than bullae.

Tuberculosis (TB):

  • TB is less likely in this scenario due to the presence of clinical features such as foul-smelling sputum, digital clubbing, and the absence of a gag reflex, which are not typical of TB.
  • Additionally, the CXR findings of a thick-walled cavity with an air-fluid level are more suggestive of a lung abscess.

questions.text: A man presents with pain and swelling of right knee joint since one week. His ankle joint and feet also started paining since past 2 days. He gives history of diarrhea 4 weeks ago. He also complains of the following lesions on his soles. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of acute arthritis following a recent infection and additive pattern (involvement of new joints within few days) and examination finding of keratoderma blennorrhagica (image) are suggestive of reactive arthritis. 

Keratoderma blennorrhagica is a mucocutaneous manifestation of reactive arthritis. It presents as vesicles and pustules that lead to hyperkeratotic lesions or crusting on the palms and soles.

Other mucocutaneous manifestations of reactive arthritis include:

  • Oral ulcers - superficial, transient, and often asymptomatic
  • Circinate balanitis - consists of vesicles that rupture to form painless superficial erosions on the glans penis

questions.text:
Calculate the anion gap from the following values:
Na+ = 137 mmol/L
K+ = 4 mmol/L
Cl- = 100 mmol/L
HCO3- = 15 mmol/L
questions.solution:
The anion gap is 22 mmol/L.

The “anion gap” (which is only a diagnostic concept) is the difference between measured cations and measured anions and is estimated as:

Plasma anion gap = [Na+ ] − [HCO3− ] − [Cl− ]

Substituting the values = 137−15−100 = 22 mmol/L

The normal anion gap ranges between 8-16 mmol/L.

The concentrations of anions and cations in plasma must be equal to maintain electrical neutrality. Therefore, there is no real “anion gap” in the plasma. 

However, only certain cations and anions are routinely measured in the clinical laboratory. The cation normally measured is Na+, and the anions are usually Cl− and HCO3−.

Usually, the unmeasured anions exceed the unmeasured cations.

The anion gap will increase if unmeasured anions rise or if unmeasured cations fall:

  • Unmeasured cations - calcium, magnesium, and potassium
  • Unmeasured anions - albumin, phosphate, sulfate, and other organic anions

Decreased anion gap (<6 mEq/L) is seen in:

  • Increase in unmeasured cations
  • An addition of abnormal cations to the blood, such as:
    • Lithium (lithium intoxication)
    • Cationic immunoglobulins (plasma cell dyscrasias)
  • Reduction in the plasma anion albumin concentration (nephrotic syndrome, liver disease, or malabsorption)
  • Hyperviscosity and severe hyperlipidemia, can lead to an underestimation of sodium and chloride concentrations.

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

High Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (MUDPILES) Normal Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (FUSED CAR)
Methanol Fistula pancreatic
Uremia (Renal failure - Acute or Chronic) Ureterosigmoidostomy
Diabetic ketoacidosis Small bowel fistula
Paraldehyde Extra chloride (Hyperalimentation)
Iron tablets, INH Diarrhea
Lactic acidosis Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (acetazolamide)
Ethylene glycol Addison's disease
Salicylates Renal tubular acidosis

questions.text: The bivalent vaccine against Human papilloma virus serotypes is ______
questions.solution:
Bivalent vaccine against HPV 16 and 18 is known as Cervarix. Cervarix is given at 0, 1 and 6 months.

Quadrivalent vaccine against HPV 6, 11, 16 and 18 is known as Gardasil or Silgard is given at 0, 2 and 6 months.

Nonavalent vaciine against HPV 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52 and 58. 

Recent update: Gardasil 9 has received expanded indication which now includes the prevention of oropharyngeal and head and neck cancers caused by HPV types 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes with tooth defects. Her radiograph of the skull shows salt and pepper appearance. There is also loss of lamina dura in tooth. The most likely diagnosis is ______.
questions.solution:
A 45-year-old woman having salt and pepper appearance in the skull with dentine defects and loss of lamina dura most likely suggests hyperparathyroidism.

Radiological features of hyperparathyroidism:

  • Classical and pathognomonic feature of hyperparathyroidism is sub-periosteal cortical resorption of middle phalanges, seen especially in the second and third fingers. This feature can also be visualized in the lateral end of clavicle and symphysis pubis.
  • Loss of lamina Dura (thin cortical bone of tooth socket surrounding teeth is seen as a thin white line)
  • Generalized osteopenia, thinning of cortices, and indistinct bony trabeculae
  • Expansile lytic lesion, otherwise known as brown’s tumor generally affecting maxilla/mandible
  • Salt and pepper appearance of the skull

In the given X-ray there are subperiosteal cortical resorption in middle and distal phalanges which points to the diagnosis of hyperparathyroidism.

The given X ray of the skull shows multiple radiolucent lytic lesions which is typical of the salt and pepper appearance (pepperpot appearance) of skull seen in hyperparathyroidism.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs of Hyperparathyroidism

Rugger jersey spine: It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey.

Subperiosteal bone resorption: This is seen on the radial side of the proximal and middle phalanges of the index and middle fingers. It is the most consistent and specific finding of hyperparathyroidism and is virtually pathognomonic of the condition.

Brown tumors / Osteitis fribrosa cystica / Von Recklinghausen's disease of bone: These are composed of pseudotumors that are made up of macrophages, blood, and connective tissue. They are seen as radiolytic areas due to the reduction in the bone trabeculae.                        

Salt and pepper appearance of the skull:  Refers to multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the calvaria of the skull ( top part of the skull) due to resorption of the trabecular bone. Alternate areas of mineralization (salt-white) and decalcification (pepper-black)

Acral osteolysis: This is also known as the tufting of phalanges

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady comes with abnormal uterine bleeding. Hysterectomy was performed, and the following specimen was retrieved. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The specimen is that of a leiomyoma.

The uterine body/corpus is enlarged and deformed. The cut surface shows multiple nodules, well-circumscribed, firm, greyish-white, with a whorled appearance formed by the intersecting bundles of brown muscle fibers and white fibrous tissue. Leiomyomas can also present bleeding areas, cystic degeneration, and calcifications. The uterine cavity is compressed.

Leiomyoma:

Leiomyoma or fibroid uterus are slow-growing, benign tumors of the uterus that affect women of reproductive age. They occur due to smooth muscle proliferation in response to estrogen and progesterone produced by the body. 

Conditions with hormone excess such as reproductive age group, hyperestrogenism, pregnancy, and oral contraceptives are associated with increased growth of fibroids. 

Fibroids are formed in the intramural (interstitial), submucous, and subserous parts of the uterus. They can also form in the extrauterine structures such as round ligament, uterosacral ligament, vagina, and vulva. 

Patients usually present with menorrhagia, metrorrhagia, infertility, recurrent abortions, pain, pressure symptoms, abdominal mass, and vaginal discharge. However, many women are asymptomatic. 

Fibroids can undergo secondary changes such as atrophy, calcareous degeneration, and red degeneration.

questions.text: A primigravid woman at 34 weeks of gestation was taken for emergency cesarean section after presenting with premature rupture of membranes and severe abdominal pain. Laparotomy revealed patches of dark port wine color over the uterus. In which of the following conditions can this complication be expected?
questions.solution:
The laparotomy finding is suggestive of uteroplacental apoplexy/Couvelaire uterus, and this complication can be expected in abruptio placenta.

Abruptio placenta is the partial/total placental separation from its implantation site before delivery. The bleeding may be:

  • Revealed (blood dissects downwards between membranes and uterine wall to escape through the cervix) or
  • Concealed (blood accumulates between detached placenta and uterus)

Risk factors for abruptio placenta include prior abruption history, preterm premature rupture of membranes, and pregnancy-associated hypertension. Patients often present with sudden onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and frequent contractions.

Uteroplacental apoplexy/Couvelaire uterus is a complication seen in severe types of concealed abruptio placentae. There is massive intravasation of blood into the uterine musculature, potentially extending up to the serous coat. It is only diagnosed on laparotomy, where a port-wine-colored uterus (diffuse or patchy) is seen. Though the uterus may lose its contractility, increasing the risk of bleeding, it rarely causes uterine atony. Hence, Couvelaire uterus does not require hysterectomy until uterine atony occurs.

Other complications of abruptio placenta include: 

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Hypovolemic shock due to torrential bleeding
  • Acute kidney injury

Abruptio placenta is mostly managed by immediate delivery and management of complications such as shock with adequate blood products.

Other options: 

Option A: Placenta previa occurs when the placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment over or very near to the cervical os. Vaginal bleeding is usually painless in this condition.

Option B: Preeclampsia is a multisystem disorder that occurs after 20 weeks due to the new onset of hypertension and proteinuria. Patients complain of headaches, epigastric pain, decreased urine output, and blurring of vision.

Option D: Uterine inversion is a complication that occurs in the third stage of labor. The uterus is partially/completely turned inside out due to various factors, such as fundally implanted placenta, uterine atony, placenta accrete syndrome, and cord traction before the placenta is separated. It produces acute lower abdominal pain with a bearing down sensation and leads to massive bleeding.

questions.text: Major constituent of soda lime is
questions.solution:
The major constituent of soda lime is calcium hydroxide.

Related Pearl: Composition of CO2 Absorbers in rebreathing system

SODA LIME:

  • Ca(OH)2 - 80%
  • NaOH - 3%
  • KOH - 2%
  • Silica - 0.2%
  • Moisture-  14-19%

Granule size is 4-8 mesh

Absorbs up to 23L of CO2/100 g

With Trilene, soda-lime forms neurotoxin dichloroacetylene and pulmonary irritant phosgene gas; hence contraindicated.

Sevoflurane reacts with soda lime and produces Compound A

Method of hardness- Silica

AMSORB:

  • Ca(OH)2
  • Ca Cl2
  • CaSO4

Causes less degradation of volatile anesthetics eg. Sevoflurane to Compound A or Desflurane to Carbon Monoxide

BARALYME:

  • Ca(OH)2 80%
  • Ba(OH)2 20%
  • KOH <1%

Absorbs up to 9-18L of CO2/100 g

Desflurane can be broken down to CO by dry barium hydroxide lime.

Method of hardness: water of crystallization.

questions.text: Which of the following features does not signify severe aortic stenosis?
questions.solution:
Wide splitting of S2 is not a feature of severe aortic stenosis. On the contrary, there might be single S2 or paradoxical splitting of S2.

Features of severe aortic stenosis are:

  • Pulsus parvus et tardus
  • Palpable carotid thrill
  • Louder and late peaking of systolic murmur
  • Single S2 or paradoxical splitting of S2
  • Presence of S3 and S4 heart sounds
  • Signs of right and left ventricular failure
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy

questions.text: While prescribing levonorgestrel as post-coital emergency contraception, you would advise for ______.

choices.text: 5 mg single dose within 24 hours of unprotected intercourse
0.75 mg single dose within 24 hours of unprotected intercourse
3 mg single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse
1.5 mg single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse

questions.solution:
Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse can be used for emergency contraception. Alternatively, it can also be administered in two doses of 0.75 mg. 1st dose is taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse and the 2nd dose 12 hours apart. 

Emergency contraception refers to backup methods for contraceptive emergencies which women can use within the first few days after unprotected intercourse to prevent an unwanted pregnancy. Administration of postcoital contraceptive agents that interfere with postovulatory events that can lead to pregnancy. 

The various emergency contraceptive methods along with their mechanism of action have been described below:

  • IUCD (intrauterine contraceptive device) prevents the implantation of a fertilized ovum. It does so by acting as a foreign body within the uterine cavity. This leads to increased contractility, and tubal peristalsis, and promotes leukocytic infiltration in the endometrium. 
  • Ulipristal is given as a 30 mg tablet and should be taken within 5 days. It is a synthetic progesterone hormone receptor modulator. The drug attaches to the progesterone receptor, delays ovulation, and suppresses endometrium, thereby preventing implantation.
  • Ethinyl estradiol 50 μg + norgestrel 0.25 mg is administered as two tablets within 72 hours of coitus followed by the 2 tablets after 12 hours. The hormone may delay ovulation if taken soon after intercourse. 
  • Centchroman is administered as two tablets of 60 mg taken twice over a duration of 24 hours and within 24 hours of intercourse. It acts by preventing the implantation of the blastocyst in the endometrium. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A professor demonstrates Moro reflex on a healthy child. He tests you by listing out the abnormal responses of this reflex and the conditions where those are seen. Which among them is wrongly paired?
questions.solution:
Kernicterus is associated with a loss of Moro reflex, not an exaggerated Moro reflex.

In Moro's reflex, there are symmetrical extension and abduction of the upper extremities, followed by anterior flexion of the upper extremities, associated with an audible cry.

 The Moro reflex:

  • It is a primitive reflex that is very sensitive to the infant's level of alertness.
  • The Moro reflex disappears by 5-6 months of age in normal infants. 
  • It can be elicited by supporting the infant in the semierect position and allowing the infant’s head to fall backward onto the examiner’s hand.

Absent Moro reflex: caused by significant generalized disturbance of the CNS

  • Stage III HIE
  • Kernicterus

Asymmetric Moro reflex: Feature of the root, plexus, or nerve disease

  • Fractured clavicle
  • Brachial plexus injury (Erb's palsy)
  • Hemiparesis

Brisk Moro reflex 

  • Neonatal hypoglycemia
  • Can also be a normal variant in healthy infants
  • Stage I HIE

Exaggerated, stereotyped, non-habituating Moro reflex is a feature of severe bilateral intrauterine cerebral disturbance, perhaps because of the release of the brain stem from inhibitory cortical influences. It is seen in conditions such as the following:

  • Hydranencephaly
  • Severe micrencephaly vera

questions.text: A patient had received rocuronium during a surgery. An antidote was administered a drug to reverse the action of this drug. Which of the following drug's actions is not reversible by this antidote?
questions.solution:
This patient was given rocuronium, a non depolarising neuromuscular blocking drug. The antidote used for these agents is sugammadex. It is however not helpful against benzylisoquinolium neuromuscular blocking agents like mivacurium. 

Sugammadex is a cyclodextrin. It is the first selective relaxant binding agent. It acts by forming complexes with steroidal non-depolarizing agents (rocuronium, vecuronium).

Sugammadex binds to plasma rocuronium and thus decreases the plasma concentration of rocuronium. This forms a concentration gradient of rocuronium due to which it moves from the neuromuscular junction back into the circulation where it quickly bound by free sugammadex. It is not recommended to be used in patients who have severe renal impairment.

questions.text: A concerned mother rushes to the OPD with her 4-day-old infant and worriedly points to the rash that appears as shown below.  Microscopic examination of this lesion revealed neutrophils. You reassure her of its harmless, transient nature.  Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing multiple vesiculopustular lesions distributed over the arms of a newborn, with the presence of neutrophils on microscopic examination is suggestive of transient pustular melanosis.

Transient pustular melanosis is a benign condition seen more commonly among African-American neonates than Caucasian neonates. They present at birth as a vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, and palms or soles. The pustular phase lasts for 2-3 days and no therapy is required. However, the subsequent hyperpigmented macules may last for up to 3 months.

Samples from the lesion can be cultured and smears can be prepared. They contain neutrophils and will not contain bacteria or aggregates of eosinophils. This distinguishes these lesions from those of pyoderma and erythema toxicum respectively. More dangerous lesions like the vesicular eruptions of herpes simplex and staphylococcal skin infections need to be ruled out by appropriate testing. 

Other options:

Option B - Mongolian spots are slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

Option C - Erythema toxicum is another transient condition characterized by small white papules on an erythematous base, which are usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week.

Option D - Cutis marmorata is a transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of the skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with academic and behavioral problems at school over the past year was diagnosed with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder. Which of the following neurotransmitters plays a key role in the pathophysiology of this condition?
questions.solution:
Dopamine has been hypothesized as the key neurotransmitter involved in the pathophysiology of attention-deficit hyperactive disorder.

The prefrontal cortex of the brain has been implicated in Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) because of its high utilization of dopamine and its reciprocal connections with other brain regions involved in attention, inhibition, decision-making, response inhibition, working memory, and vigilance. Apart from dopamine, imbalances in the levels of norepinephrine also play a role in this disorder.

Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neuropsychiatric condition affecting children, adolescents, and adults around the world, characterized by a pattern of diminished sustained attention, and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. They often have significant impairment in academic functioning as well as in social and interpersonal situations.

The clinical features of ADHD are :

  • Inattention- difficulty focusing, distractibility, not listening or following instructions, failure to finish tasks, forgetfulness, losing/misplacing objects.
  • Hyperactivity- fidgety, unable to sit still, as though driven by a motor, hyper-talkative, interrupts, blurts out answers.
  • Impulsivity- action before thought, abrupt shifts in activity, lack of organization, jumping up in class.
  • Other symptoms may include memory and thinking deficits and specific learning disabilities. 

A variety of medications and behavioral interventions are used to treat ADHD. The most widely used medications are methylphenidate, d-amphetamine, and other amphetamines. These drugs are stimulants that affect the level of the neurotransmitter dopamine at the synapse. Interventions used to treat ADHD include several forms of psychotherapy, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy, social skills training, support groups, and parent and educator skills training. A combination of medication and psychotherapy is more effective than either treatment alone.

Other Options:

Option A. Serotonin is involved in the pathophysiology of conditions like depression, mania, schizophrenia, and anxiety.

Option B. Acetylcholine levels are implicated in diseases like Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, and Huntington's disease. 

Option D. Gamma amino butyric acid (GABA) level fluctuations are seen in diseases like schizophrenia, Huntington's disease, and various forms of epilepsy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G4P3 Rh negative female with antibody titre of 1:32 presents to the OG clinic at 30 weeks.  USG reveals features of hydrops fetalis and polyhydramnios.  Cordocentesis was performed to estimate fetal hematocrit.  Intrauterine transfusion is indicated if hematocrit is:
questions.solution:
Intrauterine transfusion is done if fetal haematocrit is <30%

More about intrauterine transfusion 

  • O negative blood group cross matched with mothers blood is used 
  • It is highly packed to achieve haematocrit of 75 -80%

Routes

  1. Intra Peritoneal :- Blood is absorbed through Diaphragmatic lymphatics 
  2. Intra vascular :- Intrahepatic portion of umbilical vein or umbilical vein at cord insertion into placenta is used
  3. Combined method of 1 and 2

questions.text: What is the range of body mass index (BMI) for class I obesity in global population?
questions.solution:
The range of BMI for class I obesity for the global population is 30.00-34.99.

People categorized as class I, class II, and class III obesity have moderate, severe, and very severe susceptibility to comorbidities respectively.

Body mass index (BMI) is a statistical index of weight-for-height that is commonly used to classify underweight, overweight, and obesity in adults. It is defined as the weight in kilograms divided by the square of the height in meters (kg/m2).

Classification Global population (kg/m2)  

Indian population

(kg/m2)
Underweight <18.5

<18.5
Normal  18.5-24.99 18.5-22.99
Overweight 25-29.99 23-24.99 (and at-risk)
Obesity >30 >25
Class I obesity 30.0-34.9  25- 29.9
Class II Obesity 35.0 to 39.9  >30
Class III Obesity (severe, extreme, massive) ≥40  

These BMI values are age-independent and the same for both sexes.

The risks that are associated with increasing BMI are continuous and graded. They begin at a BMI above 25.

BMI fails to distinguish between muscle weight and weight due to fat. The percentage of body fat mass increases in both genders till the age of 60-65 years. It is higher in women than in men of equivalent BMI.

questions.text: What should the minimum duration of symptoms be to diagnose post-traumatic stress disorder?
questions.solution:
The duration of these symptoms should be > 1 month to label it as PTSD.

The given clinical scenario with re-experiences (flashbacks and nightmares), avoidance of the stimuli associated with the attacks, and hyperarousal (impaired sleep and anxiety) for more than one month are suggestive of post-traumatic stress disorder(PTSD).

PTSD is a psychiatric disorder characterized by increased stress and anxiety occurring after a stressful or traumatic event, (e.g., witnessing or being involved in violent accidents, crime, war, assault, kidnapping, natural disaster, life-threatening illness, physical or sexual abuse). 

The predisposing factors for this condition include:

  • Presence of childhood trauma
  • Borderline, paranoid, dependent, or antisocial personality disorder traits
  • Inadequate family or peer support system
  • Female gender
  • Genetic susceptibility to psychiatric illness
  • Recent stressful life changes
  • Recent excessive intake of alcohol

Symptoms of PTSD can be divided into four types:

  • Intrusion symptoms
    • Flashbacks- The individual may act and feel as if the traumatic event is reoccurring 
    • Nightmares of the event
  • Hyperarousal 
    • Increased startle response
    • Insomnia
    • Hypervigilance
    • Difficulty concentrating
    • Reckless and self-destructive behavior
    • Irritability and anxiety
  • Avoidance symptoms:  
    • avoiding memories, thoughts, and feelings of the event
    • avoiding external reminders of the traumatic event
  • Negative cognitions and mood associated with the traumatic event
    • Inability to remember an important aspect of the traumatic event
    • Feelings of depersonalization and derealization
    • Anhedonia
    • Negative emotional state- fear, horror, anger, guilt, or shame

Psychotherapies found to be effective for PTSD include exposure therapy, trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy, eye movement desensitization, and abreaction. SSRIs may be prescribed as first-line treatment.

questions.text: Bartholin’s gland in female is homologous to ____ gland in male.
questions.solution:
Bartholin glands are the homologues of the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands.

The ducts of these glands open in the groove between the hymen and the labia minora at approximately 5 and 7 o’clock positions. These glands are stimulated by sexual arousal. Contraction of the bulbospongiosus muscle expresses gland secretions to help in lubrication.

Clinical conditions :

  • Bartholin cyst : Caused by obstruction of the Bartholin ducts by proteinaceous material or by inflammation from infection. Symptomatic or recurrent cysts may require marsupialization or gland excision.
  • Bartholin abscess : An infected Bartholin cyst can lead to an abscess. It usually requires surgical drainage.

Related Pearl: Male and female homologous structures

Ova Primordial germ cells Spermatozoa
Labia majora Labioscrotal swelling Scrotum
Labia minora Urogenital folds Ventral aspect of the penis(penile urethra)

 		 Genital tubercle

Corpus cavernosum and spongiosum

Urethral and paraurethral glands (of Skene)

 		 Urogenital sinus  

Prostate gland
