questions.text: A 26-year-old man was brought unconscious to the casualty ward following head injury. CT was normal. However, MRI showed multiple small hemorrhages, especially in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain, with no midline shift. The probable cause is ________
questions.solution:
If a patient with head injury has a poor Glasgow Coma Score (GCS), normal findings on computed tomography (CT) scan, and evidence of hemorrhages in the corpus callosum or midbrain on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan, the patient has a diffuse axonal injury.

Diffuse Axonal Injury

  • This is a form of primary brain injury seen in high-energy accidents.
  • It is caused by damage to axons throughout the brain due to rotational acceleration and then deceleration. Axons may be completely disrupted and then retract, forming axon balls.
  • Small hemorrhages can be seen in more severe cases, especially on MRI (investigation of choice). Hemorrhage is classically seen in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain.
  • Prognosis is very poor.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Axonal Injury

Features of diffuse axonal injury
Mechanism Primarily a non-impact rotational acceleration-decceleration injury (this leads to deformation of the axons by stretching them)
Pathology

Changes in permeability of the axolemma

Axonal swelling

Intracellular calcium accumulation

Proteolysis

Collapse of the cytoskeleton
Histology

'Retraction balls or globes' - bulbous and clubbed axons. Seen earliest at 12-18 hours.
Immuno-histochemistry

Beta-amyloid precursor protein - considered to be the most reliable indicator of axon damage. Seen earliest at 2-3 hours. 

 

Retraction balls:

  • The force generated by violent shaking or rotational injury (as in a passenger ejected from the moving vehicle) can produce stretching of axons in cerebral white matter.
  • Microscopic examination does not show any axonal injuries up to 12 hrs after injury
  • After 12 hrs the axons first appear dilated then club shaped and finally appear as round balls known as retraction balls which indicates transected axons.
  • The number of retraction balls begins to decrease after 2-3 weeks after injury and cluster of microglial cells appear followed by astrocytosis and demyelination.

Image shows scattered axonal retraction balls stained with Congo Red (arrows):

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is referred for evaluation of a possible inherited bleeding disorder.  She has a history of easy bruising and frequent nosebleeds resulting in anemia.  Platelet count and platelet morphology on smear is normal.  The bleeding time is prolonged.  Platelet function studies show an absence of secondary aggregation to ADP, epinephrine, and collagen but a normal response to ristocetin.  The likely diagnosis is _________
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and aggregation pattern is typical for Glanzmann thrombasthenia.

It is an abnormality of platelet GPIIb-IIIa (fibrinogen receptor). Platelets are unable to adhere to each other. It is an autosomal-recessive disorder. The symptoms include mucocutaneous bleeding in the neonatal period, menorrhagia, ecchymoses, epistaxis, and gingival hemorrhage.

Laboratory features:

  • Normal platelet count and morphology
  • Platelet aggregation occurs in response to ristocetin
  • Clot retraction is absent.

Related Pearl: Platelet disorders

Finding

Bernard–Soulier syndrome

Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia

von Willebrand Disease
 Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Autosomal recessive

 Most common (Type 1): Autosomal dominant
 Defect Absence of Gp Ib-IX-V receptor Absence Gp IIb/IIIa receptor

Type 1: Partial quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor (VWF)

Type 2: Qualitative defect of VWF

Type 3: Complete quantitative deficiency of VWF 
 Mechanism

Adhesion defect: Platelets cannot adhere to subendothelium because of the lack of receptors (Gp Ib-IX-V) for VWF, which mediates platelet adhesion.

 

 Aggregation defect: Platelets cannot aggregate because of lack of receptors (Gp IIb/IIIa) for fibrinogen that form the bridges between platelets during aggregation.

 1. Platelet adhesion defect: Normally VWF binds to platelet GPIB-IX receptor and collagen in the subendothelium

2. Factor VIII deficiency- Normally VWF binds to factor VIII in circulation and prevents its degradation
Platelet count  Normal platelet count/ mild Thrombocytopenia  Normal  Normal (Except in type 2B- thrombocytopenia)
Platelet morphology Large platelets/ megathrombocytes with dense granules Normal  Normal/ large
Bleeding time

Prolonged

 Prolonged  Prolonged
Platelet aggregation tests (collagen, ADP, thrombin) Normal Abnormal  Normal
Ristocetin aggregation test

 Abnormal (platelets does not aggregate)

Does not normalize after addition of normal serum

 Normal (aggregation of platelets) Abnormal, Normalizes after addition of normal serum
VWF factor levels Normal Normal  Decreased
PT/PTT Normal Normal  PT normal, aPTT prolonged

questions.text: All of the following are correct about axillary vein thrombosis EXCEPT_______

choices.text: May be caused by cervical rib
Embolectomy will be done in all cases

questions.solution:
Embolectomy is done only in severe cases of axillary vein thrombosis.

Axillary-Subclavian Vein Thrombosis (ASVT) are 2 types:

  • Primary ASVT (also known as Paget-Schrotter Syndrome /Venous Thoracic Outlet Syndromeor Effort Thrombosis)
    • Occurs as a result of compression of subclavian vein in the costoclavicular space during repetitive or strenuous activity of the upper limb.
  • Secondary ASVT
    • Occurs due to venous injury by indwelling central venous catheters, external trauma or pacemaker wires.
    • Also occurs due to hypercoagulable states
  • Symptoms and Signs:
    • Most patients present with pain, edema, and cyanosis of the upper extremity.
    • Significant superficial venous distension can be seen in arm, forearm, shoulder and anterior chest wall.
  • Investigation: doppler study is the investigation of choice
  • Treatment:
    • Anticoagulation is initiated once ASVT is diagnosed to prevent Pulmonary Embolism.
    • In severe cases, thrombolytic therapy is done using Tissue Plasminogen Activator (rtPA) or Streptokinase.
    • Adjuvant procedures following thrombolytic therapy may include balloon angioplasty for residual venous narrowing and cervical or first rib resection for thoracic outlet abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is the most sensitive in detecting Thalassemia in the population?

choices.text: Naked Eye Single Tube Red-cell Osmotic Fragility Test

questions.solution:
Naked Eye Single Tube Red-cell Osmotic Fragility Test (NESTROFT )is the most sensitive test to detect thalassemia in the population.

It has been shown to have a high sensitivity and reasonable specificity in many studies for detecting thalassemia. Hence, it is an effective screening test.

Principle: Decreased osmotic fragility of red cells in thalassemia.

Method: 

  1.  EDTA blood + 0.36% buffered saline solution. Shake the tube and leave at room temperature for 30 minutes.
  2. Shake the tube again and immediately hold the tube in front of a piece of paper with text.
NESTROFT Inference Reason
Lines visible (negative) Normal Hemolysis has occurred
Lines not seen (positive) Thalassemia Stable RBC, unable to lyse

 

Other options :

  • Hemoglobin analysis and/or genetic testing is required to confirm the diagnosis of thalassemia. Hemoglobin can be analyzed using hemoglobin electrophoresis techniques.
  • Eosin 5 Maleimide (EMA) flow cytometry is the most specific test for the diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis.
  • Fluorescein-labeled pro-aerolysin test (FLAER) is the most sensitive screening test used for screening of Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria.

questions.text: Demographic gap starts contracting in the _________ phase.
questions.solution:
Demographic gap starts contracting in the late expanding phase (STAGE 3).

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

questions.text: Which of the following heart sounds would be heard in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
S3 is normally heard during pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was diagnosed with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and started on levothyroxine 2 weeks ago. She now presents to your clinic with abdominal pain, dizziness and weight loss. Her current appearance and her appearance last month are shown below respectively. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with severe dizziness, weight loss and a history of autoimmune thyroiditis with the image showing hyperpigmentation of the skin, points to a diagnosis of Addison’s disease and hyperglycemia is not a feature of this condition.

The clinical features of Addison’s disease include:

Hormone

Clinical features
Hypoaldosteronism

Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, salt craving
Dizziness, postural hypotension
AKI due to volume depletion
Hyponatremia
Hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis
Hypocortisolism Anorexia, weight loss, fatigue, myalgia, arthralgia
Fever (increased IL-1)
Depression
Postural hypotension
Hypoglycemia
Hyponatremia (loss of feedback inhibition of ADH)
Slightly increased TSH (loss of feedback inhibition)
Hypoandrogenism Loss of libido
  Loss of pubic and axillary hair
Elevated ACTH Hyperpigmentation

Levothyroxine can precipitate adrenal insufficiency or crisis in undiagnosed patients. In patients with concurrent adrenal insufficiency and hypothyroidism, a course of steroids must be given before giving thyroid replacement.

questions.text: A young patient with Hepatitis E virus infection develops acute liver failure. Which of the following scores can be used in assessing the prognosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with acute liver failure, MELD score and King's College Hospital criteria can be used to assess the prognosis.

Child-Pugh score is used to assess the severity of the cirrhosis.

Pitt score is used used to predict mortality in patients having bloodstream infections.

Related Pearl: Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system

Components:

  • Creatinine
  • Bilirubin
  • International normalized ratio (INR)
  • Serum Sodium (mEq/L)

Uses:

  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation (Ex: In acute liver failure)
  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to the paediatrician with complaints of bilateral knee pain. His bone mineral density is normal.  The X-ray image of the joints is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the X-ray showing Pelkan spurs, Trummerfeld zone, and Frenkel's line are suggestive of scurvy.

Radiological findings in scurvy:

  • Frenkel's line - Zone of provisional calcification at the growing metaphysis is seen as a dense, white line called the Frankel's line.
  • Pelkan spurs - These are metaphyseal spurs formed due to fractures manifesting at the cortical margins. 
  • Wimberger’s ring sign - The sclerotic rim around the epiphysis forms this appearance.
  • Trummerfeld zone. - Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line.

Scurvy results from the deficiency of vitamin C, which is required for the hydroxylation of lysine and proline in procollagen. There is the defective formation of connective tissue and collagen in the skin, bone, cartilage, dentine, and blood vessels which leads to their fragility.

Early manifestations include irritability, loss of appetite, musculoskeletal pain, and tenderness in the legs. Later on, the child can have swelling of the knees, ankles, and pseudo paralysis. Hemorrhagic manifestations of scurvy include petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses at pressure points, epistaxis, gum bleeding, and characteristic perifollicular haemorrhages.

Other manifestations are poor wound and fracture healing, hyperkeratosis of hair follicles, arthralgia, and muscle weakness. It also results in defective osteoid formation. Costo-chondral separation leads to the formation of tender nodules, which are sharply angulated also known as the scorbutic rosary.

Other options:

Option C: Metaphyseal dysplasia: It is also known as Pyle's disease. There is a failure of remodelling the metaphysis. Erlenmeyer flask deformities of the distal femur and proximal tibia are seen in this condition. The patient can also develop genu valgum.

Option D: Pycnodysostosis: It is an autosomal recessive condition due to a mutation in the cathepsin K (CTSK) gene. It causes osteosclerosis and the affected individual has distinctive facial features and skeletal malformations. The patient has short stature and is prone to recurrent fractures due to their fragile bones. 

Related Pearl: Radiological features of scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

Related Pearl: Radiological features of rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: The vulva includes ______
questions.solution:
The vulva includes mons veneris, labia majora, labia minora, clitoris, vestibule and the perineum.

  • Vulva is the collective name for external genitalia and perineum
  • Boundaries of vulva:
    • Anteriorly - Mons veneris (pubis)
    • Laterally - Labia majora
    • Posteriorly - Perineum

Development of vulva:

Part Develops from
Clitoris Genital tubercle
Labia majora Genital swellings
Labia minora Genital folds
Vestibule Urogenital sinus

questions.text: As per Sunderland's classification criteria for nerve injuries, injury to the endoneurium and the perineurium with an intact epineurium would be classified as:
questions.solution:
Injury to the endoneurium and the perineurium with an intact epineurium would be classified as grade 4.

Sunderland Classification of nerve injuries is based on the anatomical structure of the nerve. The degrees of injury are: 

  • 1°= Flow of axoplasm is partially blocked with no morphological changes. Recovery of function is complete ~ neurapraxia.
  • 2°= Axon loss occurs, but endoneurial tubes remain intact. Axons grow into their respective tubes during recovery, and the result is good ~ axonotmesis.
  • 3°= Injury to the endoneurium. During recovery, the axons of one tube can grow into another resulting in synkinesis.
  • 4°= Injury to perineurium in addition to above. Scarring impairs the regeneration of nerve fibers ~ partial transection.
  • 5°= Injury to epineurium in addition to above ~ complete nerve transection.
 

Related Pearl: Sunderland Classification of Nerve Injuries

Degree

Pathology

Previously called

1

Blocked flow of axoplasm/ conduction block

Neuropraxia

2

Loss of axons but within its endoneurium

Axonotemesis

3

Loss of endoneurium and crossed regeneration

Neurotemesis

4

Injury to perineurium and scarring

Partial transection

5

Injury to epineurium and scarring

Complete transection

questions.text: A 24-yr-old man presents with an excessive desire for sexual intercourse. What is this called?
questions.solution:
An excess desire for sexual intercourse in males is called satyriasis. 

Satyriasis is also known as Don Juanism. In some men, sexual activity is a means to mask their deep feelings of inferiority. Some have unconscious homosexual impulses, which they deny by compulsive sexual contact with women. Many of them are no longer interested in the women after sex.

Other options

  • Nymphomania: An excess desire for sexual intercourse in females
  • Frotteurism: Sexual gratification achieved by touching or rubbing against a nonconsenting person.
  • Masochism: The tendency to derive sexual gratification from one's own pain or humiliation.

Note: Don Juanism represents hypersexuality in males.

questions.text: A young female presents with dyspareunia, mucopurulent vaginal discharge and dysuria. She mentions having unprotected sexual intercourse about a week ago. Gram-staining of the discharge shows the following image. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The image depicts microscopic findings of gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes in a stained smear from the mucopurulent discharge. The patient complains of mucopurulent discharge, dyspareunia, increased urinary urgency and frequency after one week of unprotected intercourse.  This clinical scenario along with the image indicates infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted disease caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It uses pilli in adhesion to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces. The cocci penetrate the intracellular spaces to reach the subepithelial tissue by the third day of infection. The incubation period is 2-8 days.

The major symptoms include vaginal discharge, dyspareunia and dysuria, usually without urinary frequency or urgency. The specific symptoms seen in males and females are as follows:

In females:

About half the female patients remain asymptomatic. But, patients typically present with urethritis, cervical discharge, pruritus, dysuria, and intermenstrual bleeding.

The ectocervix and vagina are not usually affected in adults as the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to infection by the cocci. The acidic pH of vaginal secretions is also protective. The principal sites of invasion for gonococcal infection are the columnar and transitional epithelium.

The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, skene glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes. Unilateral pain and swelling over the labia may be caused by the inflammation of the Bartholin glands.

Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may lead to sterility. Other complications are tubo-ovarian abscesses and ectopic pregnancies. Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome). The patient presents with right upper quadrant pain and tenderness with abnormal liver function tests.

In males :

  • Acute urethritis: This infection may extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis.
  • Genital discharge: It is mucopurulent that can be described as that resembling 'flow of seed' (semen).
  • Strictures: Chronic urethritis may lead to stricture formation.
  • Water-can perineum: The infection may spread to the periurethral tissues causing abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses.

Lab diagnosis:

The discharge is collected and subjected to Gram's stain which reveals gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. Stuart's transport medium is used. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Treatment

According to CDC guidelines (2021), treatment of uncomplicated gonococcal infections is as follows:

  • Weight <150 kg – Ceftriaxone 500 mg intramuscular (IM) in a single dose
  • Weight ≥150 kg – Ceftriaxone 1 g intramuscular (IM) in a single dose

The doses of ceftriaxone are higher than the previous guidelines as the gonococcal minimum inhibitory concentrations (MICs) are rising worldwide. BASHH (British Association for Sexual Health and HIV) in the United Kingdom also recommends higher doses of ceftriaxone of about 500 mg or 1g along with azithromycin because it would result in fewer failures.

Concurrent chlamydial infection must also be treated unless it has been excluded by molecular testing. First-line drugs used are as follows:

  • Oral azithromycin 1g single dose
  • Oral doxycycline 100 mg BD for 7 days (non-pregnant patients only)

The third-generation cephalosporins are contraindicated in patients with a history of IgE-mediated penicillin allergy. The treatment includes:

  • Gemifloxacin 320mg oral + Azithromycin 2g oral
  • Gentamicin 240mg (IM)+ Azithromycin 2g oral

The sexual partners of the patient must be treated to reduce the risk of recurrence. Expedited partner therapy refers to the index patient delivering therapy to one's own partners. However, this type of empirical therapy ignores the importance of direct counseling.

 

Other options :

Option A: Chlamydial infection on Gram's staining will show leukocytes without organisms.

Option B: Trichomonas vaginalis infections show motile trichomonads on wet mount, as shown in the image below. 

Option C. Gardnerella vaginalis/ bacterial vaginosis shows presence of clue cells, as shown in the image below.

questions.text: A female patient who underwent dilatation and curettage following a missed abortion now presents with amenorrhoea. The urine pregnancy test is negative. Hysterosalpingography shows the findings seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history along with the presence of multiple, linear, irregular filling defects on hysterosalpingography suggests a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

Asherman syndrome is a condition characterized by the presence of scar tissue in the endometrial cavity.

It refers to the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of the endometrium. It can occur as a result of trauma to the endometrium following vigorous curettages for elective abortion, tuberculous endometritis, and uterine surgeries.

Patients present with features such as oligomenorrhoea, amenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, and synechiae due to uterine adhesions.

The following factors predispose a patient to develop Asherman syndrome:

  • Vigorous curettage following postpartum hemorrhage or abortion
  • Genital tuberculosis
  • Schistosomiasis

Hysterosalpingography is performed to assess the uterine cavity and tubal patency. Intrauterine adhesions are characteristically seen as irregular angulated filling defects in the uterine cavity with a classic 'moth-eaten' appearance. 

Definitive diagnosis (gold standard) and management are done by hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the surgical treatment of choice.

Hormonal assays also aid in the diagnosis of anatomical causes of amenorrhea such as Asherman syndrome. All women with amenorrhea in the reproductive age group are considered pregnant unless proven otherwise by negative urinary or serum β-HCG levels. Once negative for pregnancy, further testing is done by a progesterone challenge test.

This test is done by administering medroxyprogesterone acetate as a 10-mg daily oral dose for 10 days. If the woman bleeds, then she is assumed to produce estrogen and to have a developed endometrium, and the presence of a patent outflow tract is confirmed. If she does not bleed, then she is given estrogen followed by progesterone treatment in the form of combined OCPs. If she fails to bleed after completing the 21 hormone-containing pills, then an anatomic abnormality is diagnosed such as Asherman syndrome.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male patient comes with complaints of severe left great toe pain. History is significant for similar episodes in the past year. A picture of his left foot is shown below.  Which of the following interventions is best for the long-term treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical history and examination findings are suggestive of recurrent gout. Allopurinol is the best long-term therapy for this condition. 

 Hypouricemic drugs that can be used as definitive treatment for chronic gout include-

  • Xanthine oxidase inhibitors such as allopurinol, febuxostat
  • Uricosuric agents such as probenecid, lesinurad
  • Recombinant uricases such as rasburicase and pegloticase.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman was found to be pregnant at 8 weeks of amenorrhoea. She has 2-year-old twins who were born at 34 weeks gestation and had one stillborn baby, delivered at 39 weeks gestation, 3 years back. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score according to the GTPAL system?
questions.solution:
The obstetric score is G3(1+1+0+2) according to the GTPAL system. The patient has had 3 pregnancies including the present one(Gravida 3), one 39 week infant who was stillborn(Term 1), one 34 weeks gestation twin pregnancy(Preterm 1), no pregnancy loss within 20 weeks gestation(Abortion 0), and 2 living children who are twins(Living 2). Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and term/preterm. 

The obstetric score is used to summarise the past obstetric history of a pregnant woman.

GTPAL system is currently used -

G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one.
T - Term delivery, any delivery that happens at or beyond 37 weeks.
P - Preterm delivery, number of deliveries that happen between 20 to 36 weeks+6 days.
A - Abortion - any pregnancy loss that occurs before 20 weeks. This includes induced abortions, spontaneous miscarriages, and ectopic or molar pregnancies.
L - Living children at present.

GPAL system was followed earlier - 

G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability, which is 28 weeks in India This includes both live births and stillbirths
The current pregnancy is not included
Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and para. 
A - Abortion - the number of pregnancies that were lost for any reason before 20 weeks of gestation. This includes induced abortions, spontaneous miscarriages, and ectopic or molar pregnancies.
L - Living children at present

Note : This system is not used currently due to the discrepancy in scoring the pregnancy outcome between 20 to 28 weeks.

For the patient in this question, the GPAL score is G3P2A0L2.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with fever, cough, dyspnoea, arthralgia, and painful rash on the lower limbs suggestive of erythema nodosum. Chest X-ray is shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
X-ray showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, together with the presence of erythema nodosum, suggest the diagnosis of sarcoidosis.

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disorder of unknown aetiology that is characterised by the presence of non-caseating granulomas.

In acute cases, patients may typically present with Lofgren’s syndrome, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum (as shown below), uveitis, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, lethargy, and occasional fever. Patients may also present with insidious onset of cough, exertional breathlessness and radiographic infiltrates.

Investigations:

  • Lymphopenia and deranged liver function tests are usually seen.
  • Hypercalcaemia may be seen, due to increased synthesis of calcitriol – 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D, by alveolar macrophages. In some patients, there may be hypercalciuria, which can lead to nephrocalcinosis.
  • Pulmonary function test shows a restrictive lung disease, with impaired gas exchange.
  • Bronchoscopy shows typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa. Bronchial and transbronchial biopsies reveal non-caseating granulomas. An increased CD4:CD8 T-cell ratio may be seen in bronchoalveolar lavage.
  • Chest X-ray is useful for staging of sarcoidosis.
  • HRCT shows reticulonodular opacities that follow a perilymphatic distribution centred on bronchovascular bundles and the subpleural areas.

Diagnosis:

  • Presence of erythema nodosum with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray is sufficient to make the diagnosis of sarcoidosis. Tissue biopsy is not required.
  • A typical presentation with classical HRCT features may also indicate the diagnosis.
  • In all other cases, the diagnosis should be confirmed by histological examination of the involved organ.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Crohn's disease?

choices.text: For effective treatment of a Crohn's mass, only antibiotics are prescribed.
Symptomatic relapse after surgery is not related to the presence of disease during resection.
The proximal ileum is most commonly involved in Crohn's disease.
On endoscopic examination, continuous lesions are visualised, which are diagnostic of Crohn's disease.

questions.solution:
Symptomatic relapse of Crohn's disease after surgery is not related to the presence of the disease during resection. 

The course of the disease after surgery is unpredictable since surgery does not cure Crohn's disease. Symptomatic relapse is not related to the presence of the disease during resection. Instead, the probability of relapse requiring surgery is 20%, 40%, 60%, and 80 % at 5, 10, 15, and 20 years, respectively, after the resection. 

Option A - Antibiotics alone cannot treat a Crohn's mass effectively. Metronidazole and ciprofloxacin are the antibiotics that can be used in case of an abscess formation, which should be treated with drainage (and resection if needed) along with it.

Option C - The terminal ileum is most commonly involved in Crohn's disease.

Option D - On endoscopic examination, discontinuous lesions are visualized. There will be areas of colonic architecture in between areas of inflamed mucosa that are irregular and ulcerated with mucopurulent exudate; these so-called “skip lesions” are separated by intervening, normal-appearing intestine.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with irregular periods, acne & excessive hair growth. What is the first line management?
questions.solution:
The first line of treatment for this woman with signs and symptoms of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) such as irregular periods, acne & excessive hair growth (hirsutism) is lifestyle modification.

PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. A weight loss of 10% through lifestyle modifications such as diet and exercise are considered first-line.

The Rotterdam criteria are used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS:

  • Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne)
  • Menstrual abnormalities (oligomenorrhea/amenorrhea), anovulation, infertility
  • Polycystic ovaries on ultrasonography.

Sonographic criteria for polycystic ovaries include ≥ 12 small cysts or an increased ovarian volume (> 10 mL) or both. 

Management:

  • Weight reduction and lifestyle changes are considered the first-line treatment for infertility in obese women with PCOS.
  • Clomiphene citrate is the first-line pharmacological choice for ovulation induction in PCOS (Option B).
  • Gonadotropins are second-line.(Aromatase inhibitors like letrozole are now not used to treat infertility in these patients)
  • Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin (Option C). 
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. It also reduces acne and further hirsutism (Option D).
  • Anti-androgens are useful in treating hirsutism. OCP with cyproterone acetate is prescribed for PCOS patients with hirsutism. 

Surgical options include laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary. It restores endocrine levels and improves fertility. Surgery is indicated only in the case of

  • Failure of medical therapy
  • Hyperstimulation
  • Infertile women
  • Previous pregnancy losses

questions.text: A young boy presented with a cystic swelling on the left side of the floor of the mouth as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image of a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth are suggestive of a ranula.

Ranula is a mucus extravasation cyst arising from the sublingual gland. It produces a characteristic translucent swelling that gives the appearance of a frog’s belly. A ranula usually resolves spontaneously.  

A plunging ranula is a mucus retention cyst. It has mucus collecting below the gland and perforating through the mylohyoid muscle.

Other options:

Options A: Ectopic thyroid tissue is a developmental defect of the thyroid gland and is frequently found along the course of the thyroglossal duct. Lingual thyroid is the most common presentation of ectopic thyroid (shown below).

Option B: Cystic hygroma is usually seen in neonates and early childhood. They are cystic swellings filled with lymph fluid and are characteristically brilliantly translucent. They occur in the neck and can involve the parotid, submandibular, tongue, etc. The swelling is soft and partially compressible. Definitive treatment is the excision of the swelling. 

Option C: Ludwig's angina is a brawny swelling of the submandibular region that is caused by streptococcal infection. The infection tracks down to the mylohyoid muscle causing inflammation that displaces the tongue leading to dysphagia and painful airway obstruction. Management is by antibiotic therapy and decompression of the floor of the mouth by incising mylohyoid muscle.

questions.text: The Bone scan in multiple myeloma shows _____
questions.solution:
The Bone scan in multiple myeloma shows cold spot, as there is no compensatory osteoblastic activity.

Multiple myelomas are the most common primary malignant bone neoplasm in adults arising from red marrow due to the monoclonal proliferation of the plasma cells.

Related Pearl: Bone scan findings

Causes of a hot spot

Causes of a cold spot

Osteomyelitis

Bone tumors and metastases

Fibrous dysplasia

Trauma (fracture healing)

Avascular necrosis

Perthes disease

Paget’s disease

Hyperparathyroidism

Multiple myeloma

Fibrous cortical defect

Pseudoarthrosis

questions.text: A patient presenting with diabetic ketoacidosis was treated with IV insulin along with a bolus of normal saline. The initial serum glucose concentration of 350 mg/dL dropped to 250 mg/dL after two hours. BP, pulse, and urine output are normal. Which of the following intravenous fluids is administered next?
questions.solution:
In this patient, half-normal saline with 5% dextrose is administered.

Once the patient is hemodynamically stable, the normal saline infusion is replaced with half-normal saline infusion. It is done to prevent hyperchloremia that can develop from administering large volumes of saline needed to correct dehydration.

Additionally, 5% dextrose is added to half-normal saline when serum glucose concentration is 250 mg/dl and the glucose concentration is maintained between 150-200 mg/dl. This is done to avoid cerebral edema caused by a rapid change in plasma osmolality.

Steps in the management of diabetic ketoacidosis:

1) IV bolus of regular insulin (0.1 units/kg). Avoid insulin and correct potassium level first if below 3.3 meq/L. An IV bolus of normal saline until vitals become stable.

2) Titrate IV infusion of insulin according to a drop in serum glucose.

3) Once vitals are stable, switch to half normal saline. Once serum glucose concentration reaches 250 mg/dl, add 5% dextrose.

4) Treat underlying condition

5) Replace potassium loss and administer bicarbonate if acidosis is severe (pH < 7)

6) Switch to subcutaneous long-acting plus short-acting insulin regimen and wean from IV insulin infusion once a patient resumes eating.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common type of atrial septal defect?
questions.solution:
Ostium secundum is the most common type of atrial septal defect (ASD), located at mid-inter-atrial septum, in the region of the fossa ovalis.

Other options:

  • Ostium primum: lower atrial septum
  • Endocardial cushion defect/AV septal defect/AV canal defect consists of contiguous atrial and VSDs with markedly abnormal AV valves. The lesion is common in children with Down syndrome
  • Sinus venosus: high atrial septum, at the junction of superior vena cava and right atrium

Related Pearl: Locations of Congenital Heart Disease

Related Pearl: Classification of congenital heart disease

Acyanotic
Cyanotic (5TE²VP)
Left to right shunts:

Ventricular septal defect (VSD)

Atrial septal defect (ASD)

Obstructive lesions:

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

Coarctation of aorta

Infundibular stenosis

Pulmonary valve stenosis

Congenital mitral & tricuspid regurgitation
Right to left shunt:

Transposition of great vessels

Tricuspid atresia

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with an increased nighttime itching and lesions that are more during the winter months?
questions.solution:
Skin lesions that increase during the winter months and that cause more itching during the nighttime are seen with scabies.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic skin infection that is transmitted through the means of close personal contact/fomites. It is caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei var hominis or human itch mite. It leads to severe pruritis, excoriating papules, and burrows. The pruritis typically shows nocturnal exacerbations. In adults, the face is often spared. Typical sites include the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, elbows, axillae, buttocks, and genitalia. The typical lesions of scabies are burrows.

The following techniques can be used to diagnose scabies:

  • Skin scraping and microscopy - The material is scraped off with a blunt scalpel and is placed in mineral oil on a microscope slide. The presence of mites, eggs, fragments of eggshells, or scybala (hardened masses of faeces) confirms the diagnosis.
  • Dermoscopy - Useful for detecting burrows and visualizing their contents.
    • 10x magnification - mini triangle sign, maturing eggs that show minute heads of maturing mites within the egg.
    • 40x magnification - The mite in its burrow resembles a ‘jet‐with‐contrail’.
  • Adhesive-tape test - After firmly applying the adhesive side of the tape onto an appropriate skin lesion of patient, the tape is pulled off and transferred directly onto a slide for microscopy to visualize the mites.
  • Skin biopsy.

Treatment:

  • A single overnight application of 5% permethrin cream from neck to toe in adults and from head to toe in children is the drug of choice for the treatment of scabies in all ages including infants (at least 2 months old) and pregnant women.
  • Topical sulfur applications can be safely used in infants less than 2 months of age, as well as in breastfeeding and pregnant mothers.
  • Topical 1% Lindane cream is contraindicated in children, pregnant ladies, and seizure disorders as it is known to cause neurotoxicity.
  • All family members, even if asymptomatic, need to be treated simultaneously for this condition to prevent reinfection.
  • Clothing needs to be disinfected simultaneously.
  • Ivermectin and benzyl benzoate are contraindicated in pregnancy.

The image below shows a photo of a scabies burrow. The large scaly patch at the left is due to scratching. At the upper right, the scabies mite can be seen at the end of the burrow.

The Sarcoptes scabies mite is shown in the image below.

Other options:

Option A: Patients with tinea infection present with circular plaques with a sharp margin and raised edges that are itchy. 

The image below shows a lesion in tinea corporis.

Option C: Psoriasis presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scale, commonly affecting extensor surfaces such as the elbows and knees. It is often associated with nail changes and may involve systemic manifestations such as psoriatic arthritis. Given below is an image of plaque psoriasis.

Option D: Photodermatosis refers to a group of skin conditions caused or exacerbated by exposure to sunlight or UV radiation. It can result in rashes, itching, or other skin reactions, often requiring sun protection or medical treatment.

Related Pearl: Difference between classic and neonatal scabies

  Classic scabies Neonatal scabies
Site of involvement Interdigital webs, trunk, genitals, flexors, sparing of palms and soles, and skin above neck Face, scalp, palm, and soles
Morphology of Lesion Papules, pustules, excoriation, eczematization, burrow Vesicles, pustules, bullae, erosions, and ulcerations
Burrows Present Usually absent

questions.text: Which of the following is the first-line drug used to control seizures in a child presenting with febrile seizures?
questions.solution:
The first-line drug to control the seizures in febrile seizures is a benzodiazepine like midazolam or lorazepam.

Febrile seizures occur in children of the age of 6-60 months with a high-grade fever of 38°C (100.4 F) or higher without underlying CNS infections, metabolic abnormality, or prior afebrile seizures.

Risk factors:

Major:

  • Age  less than 1 year
  • Duration of fever  less than 24 hr
  • Fever range: 38-39°C (100.4-102.2°F)

Minor:

  • Family history of epilepsy
  • Daycare
  • Male gender
  • Complex febrile seizure
  • Family history of febrile seizures
  • Lower serum sodium at the time of presentation

Types of febrile seizures:

Simple febrile seizures Complex (atypical) febrile seizures
Occurs within 24 hours of the onset of fever Can occur at any time during a fever
Generalized seizures Focal seizures
Duration is <15 min Prolonged (>15 min)
No recurrence within 24 hrs of seizures Recurrent within 24 hours
Chances of going into epilepsy 1% Chances of going into epilepsy 6%

 Investigations:

  • Lumbar puncture should be performed in the first episode of seizures with fever, for all infants <6 months age (to exclude meningitis).
  • EEG and neuroimaging are advised for children with atypical febrile seizures.

Acute treatment of febrile seizures includes lorazepam and midazolam for seizures lasting more than 5 minutes. Rectal diazepam is prescribed to use at home as rescue medication if febrile seizures last more than 5 minutes. The use of antipyretics can decrease the discomfort of the child but does not reduce the risk of having a recurrent febrile seizure.

Prophylaxis:

  • Intermittent prophylaxis includes oral clobazam for 3 days during the fever episode, if the febrile seizures recur at the rate of ≥3 seizures in 6 months, or ≥4 in 1 year.
  • Continuous prophylaxis with sodium valproate and phenobarbitone can be used for failed intermittent prophylaxis and in recurrent atypical febrile seizures.

Note:

  • Intermittent oral nitrazepam, clobazam, and clonazepam have also been used. Such therapies help reduce, but do not eliminate, the risks of recurrence of febrile seizures.
  • Future epilepsy does not change with or without antiepileptic therapy.
  • Iron deficiency is associated with an increased risk of febrile seizures, and thus screening and treating it would be appropriate.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 2-year old history of erythematous papulo pustular lesions on convexities of the face. There is a background of erythema and telangiectasia. The most likely diagnosis is ____
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis is rosacea as the patient comes with erythema and papules on facial convexities (central face), a characteristic feature of acne rosacea.
  • It is triggered by exposure to sunlight, spicy food, alcohol, or emotional disturbances and is more common in women of age 30 to 50 years.

There are 4 subtypes:

  • Subtype 1: Erythematotelangiectatic rosacea (ETTR).
  • Subtype 2: Papulopustular rosacea (PPR).
  • Subtype 3: Phymatous rosacea (PR).
  • Subtype 4: Ocular rosacea (OR).

These subtypes are not equivalent to stages of progression.

Treatment:

  • Erythematotelangiectatic rosacea
    • Sun avoidance and protection
    • Non‐scented, colour‐free moisturizer
    • Soap‐free cleansers
    • Avoid factors that provoke flushing
    • Topical α‐receptor agonists such as brimonidine or oxymetazoline
  • Papulopustular rosacea
    • Sun avoidance, sun protection, moisturizing and cosmetic cover as for ETTR
    • Topical metronidazole, azelaic acid, ivermectin or sodium sulfacetamide and sulphur for active inflammatory lesions
    • Topical α‐receptor agonists such as brimonidine and oxymetazoline for perilesional erythema
  • Phymatous rosacea
    • As for PPR for accompanying inflammatory lesions
    • Topical skin‐peeling agent if there are large occluded follicles
    • Electrocautery or laser for telangiectases
  • Ocular rosacea
    • Daily lid hygiene
    • Oily tear‐substitute lubricating eye drops or aqueous gels 

Image: rosacea

questions.text:
Patient after head trauma responds to verbal stimuli with confusion, opens eyes to speech and follows simple commands and is able to localise pain. What is the GCS score?

GCS-P: Glasgow coma scale-Pupillary reactivity score
questions.solution:
The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) for the given case scenario is 12.

GCS for the given case is 12 (E3 V4 M5). 

  • E: eye opening to speech - 3
  • V: confused - 4
  • M: localizes to pain - 5

GCS is used in the assessment of patients with a head injury.

Minimum GCS value: 3

Maximum GCS value: 15

The severity of head injury based on GCS:

  • Mild- 13-15
  • Moderate- 9-12
  • Severe- 3-8

Pupillary reactivity score:

  • Both pupils unreactive to light- 2
  • One pupil unreactive to light- 1
  • Neither pupil unreactive to light- 0

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal/flexion 4
Abnormal flexion/Decorticate posturing  3
Extension/Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

Half-hourly for 2 hours,
Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
Then 2-hourly thereafter.
Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of ischemic heart disease presents with palpitations for the last 3 days. A transesophageal echo shows a thrombus in the left atrium. His ECG is shown below. Which of the following should be done to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The patient is in atrial fibrillation and it should be treated by initiating anticoagulation. 

The patient's ECG shows irregular atrial activation and an irregular ventricular rate which is suggestive of atrial fibrillation. In addition, his CHA2DS2-VASc score is 2 (history of ischemic heart disease and age of 70). These factors along with the presence of a left atrial thrombus require initiating anticoagulation.  

Electrical cardioversion is contraindicated in this patient due to his risk of stroke and the presence of an atrial thrombus.

The treatment of atrial fibrillation depends on three things: duration of symptoms, the severity of symptoms, and the risk of stroke.

The duration of atrial fibrillation - those who present within 48 hours of the onset of symptoms have a lower risk of an existing atrial thrombus and can be safely cardioverted. Those who present with unknown or known onset of more than 48 hours should ideally be anticoagulated before cardioversion. This patient has had symptoms of atrial fibrillation for at least three days. 

The severity of atrial fibrillation refers to the presence of other symptoms and signs. These could include hypotension, pulmonary edema, or angina and are reflective of the cardiac health prior to the onset of fibrillation. This patient is otherwise stable and has no other symptoms and signs of atrial fibrillation. Patients who are unstable and have developed acute onset atrial fibrillation should be reverted to normal sinus rhythm when possible. 

The risk of stroke in a patient can be calculated using the CHA2DS2-VASc score. 

Risk factors Points
Congestive heart failure 1
Hypertension 1
Age > 75 years 2
Diabetes mellitus 1
Stroke/TIA/Embolus 2
Vascular disease 1
Age 65 - 75 years 1
Sex category - female 1

Anticoagulation should be considered in those with a score of 1 and should be administered in those with a score of 2 or more. 

A combination of those three factors should be considered to determine the next best step in treatment.

Patients with onset within < 48 hours and a low risk of stroke can be cardioverted immediately. This can be done by administering a QRS synchronous shock of 200J. 

A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) can be performed at the time of presentation to look for an atrial thrombus. If none is present, then the patient can be cardioverted followed by a minimum of four weeks of anticoagulation. 

In patients with the onset of atrial fibrillation of more than 48 hours and a higher risk of stroke due to pre-existing conditions should receive anticoagulation before cardioversion. They can be anticoagulated for 3 weeks before cardioversion, followed by further 4 weeks of anticoagulation.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with cyclical abdominal pain and a midline hypogastric lump. She has not achieved menarche yet. On examination, a bluish bulge is noted on parting the labia. What is the likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of an imperforate hymen, which has led to cryptomenorrhoea. This is a condition where menstruation occurs but is not visible due to an obstruction of the outflow tract.

The menstrual fluid gets collected in the reproductive tract. When this collection occurs in the vagina, it is known as hematocolpos. If the collection extends to the uterus, it is known as hematometra. The collection of blood in the fallopian tubes is called hematosalpinx.

The most common causes of cryptomenorrhea are:

  • Intact/imperforate hymen - a bluish convex bulge is seen.
  • Transverse vaginal septum - a pinkish concave covering is seen

Ultrasound pelvis confirms the diagnosis.

Management:

Imperforate hymen - A simple cruciate incision of the hymen allows the free drainage of the collected menstrual blood, and leads to normal reproductive function.

Transverse vaginal septum - Extensive dissection and vaginoplasty is required.

Option A: Bartholin's cyst appears as a swelling on the inner side of the labia majora. Larger cysts can bulge across the introitus. Small cysts can remain asymptomatic.

Option D: Endometriomas are endometriotic lesions seen on the ovary. They present as adnexal masses. Endometriosis is a complication in cryptomenorrhea, due to retrograde menstruation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient came in with multiple thickened and discolored toenails, as shown in the figure below. Examination using a potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation revealed the presence of dermatophytic hyphae and arthrospores. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with multiple discoloured and thickened nails and dermatophytic hyphae on KOH preparation is suggestive of Tinea unguium or Onychomycosis. The treatment of choice here is oral terbinafine.

Onychomycosis is a fungal infection of the nail unit. It can be caused by dermatophytes(Trichophyton species), Fusarium, and Candida. Distal lateral subungual onychomycosis is the most common clinical type of onychomycosis. 

Oral terbinafine is the treatment of choice for Tinea unguium or onychomycosis.

FIRST-LINE DRUG DURATION
 Oral Terbinafine - 250mg/day

Fingernails - 6 weeks.

Toenails - 12 weeks
Oral Itraconazole- 400mg/day for 1week

Fingernails - regimen repeated every month for 2 to 3 months

Toenails - regimen repeated every month for 3 to 4 months

Other options:

Options A and C: Topical treatment with amorolfine or ciclopirox olamine can be used in mild infections affecting the distal nail plate only or non‐linear superficial onychomycosis. However, this patient has onychomycosis involving the proximal part of the nail plate, and multiple toenails are infected. Therefore, topical treatment alone is not the first-line treatment of choice for this patient. It can be used as an adjunct to oral therapy.

Option D: Oral griseofulvin dose 1 g/day for 4–8 months (longer for toenails) is used as a second-line treatment.

questions.text: A patient developed a lesion as shown below a few months after undergoing heart surgery. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is a keloid scar.

Keloid is a consequence of abnormal wound healing. It is suspected that overacted fibroblasts are responsible for patients developing this condition. Keloids present as firm, rubbery nodules in areas of prior skin injury.

Keloids almost always extend beyond the initial site of an injury, in contrast to hypertrophic scar.

There is a high chance of recurrence post-surgical excision, hence this must always be paired with other modalities such as intralesional steroid injections.

Other options:

Hypertrophic scars are raised, red scars that remain within the boundaries of the original wound. They are characterized by excessive collagen formation during the healing process. Unlike keloid scars, hypertrophic scars do not extend beyond the original wound site. They may regress over time and are less likely to recur after surgical excision.

Atrophic scars are characterized by a depression in the skin's surface, often resulting from a loss of underlying tissue. They can occur due to conditions like acne or trauma. They are the opposite of hypertrophic and keloid scars, as they result in a loss of tissue rather than excessive collagen formation.

Contractures are scars that cause the skin to tighten and pull, leading to reduced mobility of nearby structures. They can occur after burns or extensive tissue damage. Contractures are characterized by tightening and pulling of the skin, leading to functional limitations.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in the management of MDR TB under NTEP?
questions.solution:
PAS( para amino salicylic acid) is not included under MDR TB regimen. It is included in XDR TB regimen.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen -TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 H R Z E 4 H R E

Classification based on drug resistance

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and a second-line injectable anti TB drug (kanamycin, amikacin, or capreomycin).

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months
  • 6 months long
  • Oral drugs only
Shorter MDR TB regimen

Intensive Phase:

Mfx Km/Am Eto Cfz Z H E for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Mfx Cfz Z E for 5 months
  • 9-11 months long
  • Injectables used in intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs for 18-20 months
  • 18-20 months long
  • Oral drugs only
  • This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.


Legend

FQ: Fluoroquinolone

Lfx: Levofloxacin

H: Isoniazid

R: Rifampicin

E: Ethambutol

Z: Pyrazinamide

Mfx: Moxifloxacin

Km: Kanamycin

Am: Amikacin

Eto: Ethionamide

Cfz: Clofazimine

Bdq: Bedaquiline

Lzd: Linezolid

Cs: Cycloserine

questions.text: In a normal partograph, cervical dilatation should be on the _______
questions.solution:
In a normal partograph, cervical dilatation should be towards the left or on the alert line.

Partograph is a composite graphical record of key data (maternal and fetal) during labor, entered against time on a single sheet of paper (FIG 1).

Alert line starts at 4 cm (WHO) of cervical dilatation and ends at 10-cm dilatation (at the rate of 1 cm/h).

Action line is drawn 4 h to the right and parallel to the alert line.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The image shows the resection of the tail of pancreas followed by longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy i.e. Puestow procedure which is a treatment modality for chronic pancreatitis.

When chronic pancreatitis is accompanied by intractable pain, it is best treated with side-to-side Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy, also known as the modified Puestow procedure or lateral pancreaticojejunostomy.

Note:

Duval procedure is outdated and not in use due to low improvement rates. Restenosis and segmental obstruction of the pancreas is common due to progressive scarring. It is now only used in resectable tumors of the body or the tail of the pancreas.

Related Pearl: Drainage procedures for chronic Pancreatitis

Duval procedure: Distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy

Puestow procedure: Resection of tail followed by longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

  • Partington and Rochelle modification of Puestow procedure: Elimination of resection of pancreatic tail
  • A longitudinal pancreatotomy typically discloses segmental stenosis of the pancreatic duct and the presence of intraductal calculi in a patient with chronic calcific pancreatitis.
  • Following mobilization of a Roux limb of jejunum, a longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is performed to permit extensive drainage of the pancreatic duct system.

Related Pearl: Resection and Hybrid Surgical Procedures for Chronic Pancreatitis

Beger’s procedure: Duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection (DPPHR)

  • The completed resection after transection of the pancreatic neck and subtotal removal of the pancreatic head, with preservation of the distal common bile duct and duodenum (Marked A).
  • Completion of the reconstruction of the anastomosis to the distal pancreas and to the proximal pancreatic rim by the same Roux limb of the jejunum.

Frey’s procedure:

  • The local resection of the pancreatic head with longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (LR-LPJ) provides complete decompression of the entire pancreatic ductal system. Reconstruction is performed with a side-to-side Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy.

Warren’s modification of Beger’s procedure:

Berne modification (Beger + Frey) involves excavation of the central portion of the head without formal division of the neck.

(image below)

Hamburg modification of Frey’s procedure

Note:

Surgical treatments for chronic pancreatitis

Resection

  • Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Kausch–Whipple procedure)
  • Pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy (Traverso–Longmire)
  • Beger procedure
  • Near-total or total pancreatectomy

Decompression/Drainage

  • Duval procedure
  • Puestow–Gillesby procedure
  • Partington–Rochelle procedure (Puestow)
  • Izbicki procedure

Hybrid (resection+decompression)

  • Frey procedure
  • Hamburg modification
  • Berne modification

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman who underwent mastectomy for breast carcinoma followed by radiotherapy presented with acute worsening of swelling of the upper limb, as shown in below image. The diagnosis is _______
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is Stewart–Treves syndrome.

The development of angiosarcoma after a combination of postmastectomy lymphedema and radiation therapy is known as Stewart–Treves syndrome. It can arise de-novo or from post-mastectomy lymphedema.

Treatment is Preoperative chemotherapy and radiotherapy followed by surgical excision (radical amputation). Prognosis is poor.

Other options:

Tietze syndrome is an inflammatory condition characterized by chest pain and swelling of the cartilage around the ribs at the costochondral junction. It usually develops in people who are under the age of 40. Symptoms include mild to severe chest pain that may extend into the arms and shoulders.

Milroy's disease is a familial disease, caused by congenital abnormalities in the lymphatic system. Disruption of the normal drainage of lymph leads to fluid accumulation and hypertrophy of soft tissues. The most common presentation of Milroy Disease is bilateral lower extremity lymphedema, and may also be accompanied by hydrocele. Males and females may have upslanting toenails, deep creases in the toes, wart-like growths (papillomas), and prominent leg veins. Episodes of cellulitis can cause further swelling in the lower limbs.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male student with cystic fibrosis developed acute onset cough which was worsening progressively, along with wheezing and increased sputum production. A probable diagnosis of of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) has been made. Which of the following is the incorrect option regarding the serological diagnosis for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) in a patient with cystic fibrosis. ABPA is diagnosed serologically, based on the detection of aspergillum-specific IgE or positive skin prick test and serum IgE > 1000 IU/ml. IgG antibodies to Aspergillus flavus are seen in chronic aspergillus sinusitis.

Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis:

ABPA is an eosinophilic pulmonary disorder caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to the colonisation of airways by the fungus Aspergillus fumigatus. It occurs almost exclusively in patients with asthma (~2.5% of patients) or cystic fibrosis (up to 15%). In chronic cases, repeated episodes of bronchial obstruction, inflammation, and mucoid impaction can lead to bronchiectasis, fibrosis and respiratory compromise.

With the development of ABPA, asthma or CF typically worsens and may manifest with a new or worsening cough or an increase in sputum production or wheezing. Many patients report coughing up thick sputum casts.

The presence of hyperattenuated mucus in airways is highly specific. While central bronchiectasis is characteristic, some patients can develop chronic cavitary lesions.

ABPA is diagnosed serologically, based on the presence of:

  • Serum IgE > 1000 IU/ml.
  • Positive skin prick test in response to A.fumigatus extract.
  • Detection of Aspergillus-specific antibodies.
  • Eosinophilia >500 cells/μL.

questions.text: Non-immune hydrops fetalis is caused by ________.
questions.solution:
Both alpha-thalassemia and parvovirus B19 infection cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis. 

Hydrops fetalis refers to the abnormal fluid collections in fetal soft tissues and serous cavities. Edema, signs of heart failure, and profound intra-uterine anemia are the presenting features in the fetus. Other clinical features include marked hepatosplenomegaly, retardation in brain growth, hydrocephaly, urogenital and cardiovascular deformities, and extramedullary erythropoiesis.

Non-immune hydrops fetalis (NIHF) comprises the subgroup of cases not caused by red cell alloimmunization (e.g., Rh(D), Kell).

questions.text:
Match the following:
1. Workshop

A. Series of lectures on a subject by experts after which the audience is allowed to ask questions
2. Symposium B. Incorporates a variety of methods like speeches, and discussions, and may last for half a day to a week.
3. Roleplay C. Series of meetings emphasizing individual work within the group
4. Seminar

D. Dramatization of social situations for health education
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

A workshop is a series of meetings with an emphasis on individual work within the group. External consultants or experts may be involved.

A symposium is a series of lectures on a selected subject by experts after which the audience is allowed to ask questions (no discussion is involved).

Role play is the dramatization of social situations for health education by those taking part in it.

Seminars are similar to conferences and incorporate a variety of methods like speeches, and discussions for health education, which may last for half a day to a week.

Methods of Health Communication    
Individual approach Group approach Mass approach
