  2. Home visits
  3. Personal letters
  1. Lectures
  2. Demonstrations
  3. Discussion methods
    • Group discussions
    • Panel discussion
    • Symposium
    • Workshop
    • Conferences
    • Seminars
    • Roleplay
  1. TV
  2. Radio
  3. Newspaper
  4. Printed material
  5. Direct mailing
  6. Posters
  7. Health museums
  8. Health exhibitions
  9. Folk method
  10. Internet

questions.text:
A patient underwent a TAPP repair for an incarcerated left inguinal hernia. While fixing the mesh, tacks were accidentally placed below the iliopubic tract. On follow-up visits, the patient complained of persistent pain in his lateral thigh. Which of the following injury has most likely caused the pain?

TAPP - Transabdominal Preperitoneal
questions.solution:
Injury to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most likely cause of pain in the above scenario.

It can be injured in laparoscopic hernia repair. 

In laparoscopic TAPP repair, to reduce chances of nerve injury during mesh placement, tacks are ideally placed above the iliopubic tract (away from the triangle of pain which carries the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve, and the femoral nerve).

Other options:

Option A: Ilioinguinal nerve may be commonly injured during open hernia repair. It provides innervation to the groin and medial aspect of the thigh, the upper part of the scrotum, and the penile root.

Option B: Iliohypogastric nerve can be injured while making an incision in the right iliac fossa during hernia surgery. It mainly supplies the suprapubic skin.

Option C: Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve (which supplies the skin over the upper anterior part of the thigh) lies in close relation to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. Injury to these also can cause loss of sensation over the thigh but these are less frequent.

 

 

Related Pearl: The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

It is bounded

  • Superio-medially by gonadal vessels
  • Laterally by peritoneum
  • Inferio-laterally by the iliopubic tract

Contents:

  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Anterior femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerves

Related Pearl: The triangle of doom

The triangle of doom is bounded

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at internal ring.

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Femoral nerve
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of excess uncontrollable worry over daily life activities, finances, and his health for the past 2 years. Because of this, he feels restless most of the time. He also complains of fatigue and disturbed sleep. Which of the following screening tools is useful for identifying this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a generalised anxiety disorder(GAD). The GAD-7 scale is used in the assessment of generalized anxiety disorder. 

When assessing for GAD, clinical professionals look for the following according to the DSM-5 (and ICD-11) criteria: 

  • The presence of excessive anxiety and worry about a variety of topics, events, or activities.
  • Worry occurs more often than not for at least six months and is clearly excessive.
  • The worry is experienced as very challenging to control.
  • The worry in both adults and children may easily shift from one topic to another.
  • The anxiety and worry are accompanied by at least three of the following physical or cognitive symptoms (In children, only one of these symptoms is necessary for a diagnosis of GAD):
  • Edginess or restlessness
  • Tiring easily; more fatigued than usual Impaired concentration or feeling as though the mind goes blank
  • Irritability (which may or may not be observable to others)
  • Increased muscle aches or soreness
  • Difficulty sleeping (due to trouble falling asleep or staying asleep, restlessness at night, or unsatisfying sleep)

Other options:

Option A: Patient Health Questionnaire 9 (PHQ-9) is a tool used to assess depressive symptoms in patients with major depressive disorder. 

Option B: CHAT checklist is used in autism (CHecklist for Autism in Toddlers).

Option D: Confusion assessment method (CAM) is a bedside screening test used in the diagnosis of delirium.

questions.text: Exclamation mark hair pattern is seen in:
questions.solution:
Exclamation mark hair pattern is seen in alopecia areata.

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes non-scarring hair loss. It is a T-cell mediated inflammatory disease. It is associated with several autoimmune diseases including thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo, and psoriasis.

It mainly affects the scalp, but can also affect the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes. In some cases, this progresses to a total loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or a loss of all hair on the body (alopecia universalis).

The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia. Some broken hairs can be seen which are called exclamation marks. They are easily extractable. It preferentially affects pigmented hair and spares white hair. It can cause fine stippled pitting of the nails and roughening of the nail bed, which is called trachyonychia.

Histopathology will show perifollicular and intrafollicular T lymphocyte infiltration.

Spontaneous remission occurs in a majority of patients. Topical steroids like clobetasol can be useful in patchy alopecia areata. Intralesional steroids are the most effective treatment for patchy alopecia areata. A depot steroid-like triamcinolone administered by fine-needle injection into the upper subcutis can stimulate hair growth at the site. Multiple injections are usually required.

Severe and long-standing alopecia areata requires oral corticosteroids.

Other options:

Option B: Trichotillomania (trichotillosis) is considered an obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) spectrum disorder, marked by gratification from pulling one's own hair. It could be associated with underlying anxieties or depression. The vertex region of the scalp is most commonly involved. Scalp histology will show perifollicular hemorrhages and intrafollicular pigment casts. 

Option C: Telogen effluvium leads to diffuse hair loss that affects all hair equally, not just pigmented hair. So, overall hair color will not be affected.

Option D: Androgenic alopecia is a disorder characterized by a reduction of hair fibre production by follicles and miniaturization. Dihydrotestosterone, an androgenic metabolite, is implicated in the etiology. It is of two types, male pattern and female pattern hair loss. Male pattern hair loss causes frontal hairline recession and thinning of the vertex.  Female-pattern hair loss involves the mid-frontal scalp diffusely. There is no or minimal involvement of the temporal region.

questions.text: The critical obstetric conjugate for trial of labor is ______.
questions.solution:
The clinically important obstetric conjugate is the shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis.

Normally, this measures 10 cm or more, but unfortunately, it cannot be measured directly by the examiner's fingers. For clinical purposes, the obstetrical conjugate is estimated indirectly by subtracting 1.5–2 cm from the diagonal conjugate, which is determined by measuring the lowest margin of the symphysis to the sacral promontory.

The red line marked 4 is the obstetric conjugate. The red line marked 5 is the pelvic outlet.

questions.text: Identify the type of injury in the image given below.
questions.solution:
Degloving injury occurs when the skin and subcutaneous fat are stripped by avulsion from its underlying fascia, leaving neurovascular structures, tendon or bone exposed.

It may be open or closed.

A tidy wound is a clean incised wound with seldom tissue loss whereas an untidy wound is one which is crushed, avulsed, contaminated often with tissue loss.

questions.text: Given figure depicts the different waveforms of JVP. The waves 1 and 4 in the figure are___?
questions.solution:
The waves 1 and 4 in the figure are a wave & x descent, which corresponds to atrial contraction and atrial relaxation respectively.

Jugular venous pressure measured in the internal jugular vein is a reflection of the right atrial pressure. A normal waveform has the following deflections.

  • a wave: corresponds to Atrial contraction
  • c wave: corresponds to the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular contraction.
  • x descent: corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole
  • v wave: corresponds to the venous filling of the right atrium
  • y descent: passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle

The relation with ECG and different chamber pressures are :

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: Which is the characteristic pattern seen in Brown Sequard syndrome?

choices.text: Contralateral loss of joint sense and position
Ipsilateral loss of complete sensory functions

questions.solution:
The Brown–Sequard syndrome presents with contralateral loss of pain sensation.

Lateral hemisection of the spinal cord produces the Brown–Séquard syndrome.

Clinical features

  • Ipsilateral weakness (corticospinal tract involvement) 
  • Ipsilateral loss of joint position and vibratory sense (posterior column involvement)
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense (spinothalamic tract involvement) one or two levels below the lesion
  • Ipsilateral segmental signs like radicular pain, muscle atrophy, or loss of a deep tendon reflex

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: Which among the following is discarded in the bin shown in the image below?
questions.solution:

Cotton swabs contaminated with blood and blood bags are discarded in the yellow bin. Ampules are discarded in blue puncture-proof containers.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with a blood type O negative blood group presents to the transplant clinic to discuss proceeding with allogeneic stem cell transplant. Which of the following would be an optimal donor?

choices.text: His human leukocyte antigen (HLA) identical 50-year-old brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+
An HLA identical matched unrelated donor who is blood type O–

questions.solution:
HLA-identical sibling who is healthy and ABO compatible would be an optimal donor.

For hematologic malignancies, the syngeneic transplant has proven to result in higher relapse rates and would not be the recommended donor source. While ABO compatibility is important to consider in deciding an optimal donor, this is only a minor ABO mismatch.

Related donor transplants remain preferred to unrelated donor transplants, given that the lower rates of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) with related transplants.

There is no role for an umbilical cord transplant in a setting with available related donors.

questions.text: A  man suffering from ulcerative colitis for the past several years presents with jaundice and pruritus. Investigations showed elevated serum alkaline phosphatase and MRCP showed beading in the bile ducts. Biopsy finding reveals onion skin fibrosis of the bile duct as shown below. Which of the following is true about the disorder that has caused this jaundice?

choices.text: Antimitochondrial antibodies present in most patients

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of jaundice and pruritus, elevated serum alkaline phosphatase, MRCP showed beading in the bile ducts, with biopsy showing onion skin fibrosis and a past history of ulcerative colitis all point toward a diagnosis of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). The true statement about this condition is- p-ANCA is positive.

Primary sclerosing cholangitis is a chronic cholestatic disease resulting from inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of both intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts (Option C).

This results in features of obstructive jaundice such as icterus, pruritus which can be debilitating, high colored (dark) urine, and pale stools. They also present with profound fatigue, steatorrhea, and fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies. Up to 75% of people with PSC have inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

Laboratory findings reveal a two-fold or greater increase in alkaline phosphatase levels, deranged aminotransferase levels, and prolonged prothrombin time. 

The diagnosis can be confirmed by performing an MRCP (magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography). ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography) can also be performed to further localize areas of increased strictures. The cholangiography findings include multifocal strictures with intervening dilated bile duct segments. This produces a classic beaded appearance. 

There is no specific medical management for PSC. Endoscopic dilatation of the strictures may help to improve symptoms. Definitive management is only with liver transplantation.

PSC has the risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma (Option A). Patients with IBD and PSC are at an increased risk for colon cancer, hence, they should receive annual screening colonoscopies.

The below image shows a cholangiogram of primary sclerosing cholangitis. There are diffuse strictures of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts with dilatation of the areas in between:

 

Other options-

Option (B): Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are seen in most patients with primary biliary cholangitis, and not in PSC.

questions.text: A cricket player was hit on the head with the cricket ball and was fine and then collapsed suddenly. He woke up to play the match brilliantly but was later found unconscious in the dressing room. His CT was taken which is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of lucid interval along with the CT image showing a bi-convex hyperdense lesion is suggestive of extradural hemorrhage.

The patient is initially unconscious from the concussive aspect of the head trauma. The patient then awakens and has a lucid interval, while the hematoma sub-clinically expands. As the volume of the hematoma grows, intracranial pressure (ICP) increases, and the patient rapidly becomes lethargic and herniates.

Extradural hemorrhage is most commonly due to bleeding from the middle meningeal artery. As the dura mater tends to adhere to the skull, the hematoma collecting between the skull and this dura is seen on CT sections as a biconvex dense area immediately beneath the skull vault, convex towards both the brain and the vault. They tend not to cross the suture lines.

The temporoparietal convexity is the most common site. The hematoma usually lies beneath a fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone. The underlying brain is displaced but often appears intrinsically normal.

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhage

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient is diagnosed with a fracture of the neck of the femur. T- score on a DEXA scan is -3.0. Which of the following drugs used for this condition acts as a sclerostin inhibitor?
questions.solution:
A T-score of -3.0 in a DEXA scan, along with a fragility fracture, is suggestive of severe osteoporosis. Romosozumab is a monoclonal antibody that acts as a sclerostin inhibitor indicated in this condition.

Radiological osteopenia can be diagnosed from an X-ray where the bone appears less dense than normal. Typical signs are loss of trabecular definition, thinning of cortices, and insufficiency fractures.

DEXA (Dual Energy Xray Absorptiometry) is used to assess bone mass density after a fracture due to a trivial fall or as a preventative measure for adults aged over 60. It has two scores: T-score (compares bone density with that of younger population) and Z-score (compares bone density with the same age group).

Values of T-scores
≥ -1.0 Normal bone density
-1.0 to -2.5 Osteopenia
≤ -2.5 Osteoporosis
≤ -2.5 plus fragility fracture Severe Osteoporosis

 

Treatment options for osteoporosis include:

  • Bisphosphonates - first-line treatment to reduce postmenopausal osteoporosis. It includes oral drugs such as alendronate, risedronate, and i.v. formulations such as zoledronate (given only once per year). They act by reducing bone resorption and the rate of bone turnover.
  • Denosumab (Option C) - a monoclonal antibody that acts against the RANK-L which is essential for promoting osteoclast formation. It is given subcutaneously once every 6 months.
  • Romosozumab - a monoclonal antibody that acts as a sclerostin inhibitor and has been shown to increase bone formation.
  • Parathyroid hormone - Teriparatide, a synthetic agent given intermittently at low doses to promote bone formation.
  • Strontium ranelate - a drug that promotes bone formation and reduces bone turnover but is used in limited areas due to its adverse effects.
  • Selective estrogen receptor modulators - Raloxifene, a second-line drug used to reduce future risk of fracture reduction in postmenopausal women.

Other options:

Option B: Odanacatib acts as a cathepsin-K inhibitor which is an enzyme in osteoclast that facilitates bone resorption.

Option D: Pembrolizumab is a humanized IgG4 monoclonal antibody that acts against PD1 and can be used in the treatment of melanoma and small-cell carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score of -2.5 or lower, that is, a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image below:
questions.solution:
The given image shows placenta previa.

The grades of placenta previa are:

  • Type I (Low-lying): The major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the
    lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the os.
  • Type II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the
    internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).
  • Type IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely explanation for symmetrical uptake in bilateral supraclavicular areas with no uptake on paratracheal nodes on PET-CT in a patient with ca esophagus?

choices.text: Recent viral upper respiratory tract infection

questions.solution:
• 18F-FDG PET-CT is the current modality of choice to evaluate for metastases and demonstrates brown fat as areas of high uptake. It is a potential source of false-positive FDG PET interpretations in oncologic imaging.

 Areas of Normal physiological uptake in PET CT:

  • Brain tissue
  • Skeletal muscle, especially after strenuous activity and laryngeal muscles following speech
  • Myocardium
  • Gastrointestinal tract, e.g. intestinal wall
  • Genitourinary tract: FDG is excreted via the renal system and passes into the collecting systems
  • Brown fat
  • Thymus
  • Bone marrow

questions.text: In a community of 5000, the crude birth rate is 30 per 1000 people. The number of pregnant females is?
questions.solution:
The number of pregnant females is 165.

Step 1: In the given question, the crude birth rate is 30 per 1000 people i.e 30 children are born from pregnant mothers for every 1000 people. Therefore there are 30 pregnant females per 1000 population.

Step 2: Since the total population is 5000, the total no of pregnant females = 30 x 5000/1000 = 150 

Step 3: We should also consider the pregnancy wastage i.e 10% of total live births =10 x 150/100=15 (since some pregnancies may not result in live birth i.e abortions and stillbirths, a correction factor of 10% is to be added to avoid the underestimation of the number of pregnancies)

Step 4: Total pregnant females = total live birth + pregnancy wastage = 150+15=165.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to PHC with complaints of URI, fever, sandpaper rash over her trunk and extremities. Treatment of her condition will prevent which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Upper respiratory infection with sandpaper rash is suggestive of scarlet fever which is caused by beta-hemolytic streptococci.

It is important to note that there are many post-infection sequelae such as rheumatic fever, glomerulonephritis, reactive arthritis, PANDAS(pediatric autoimmune neuropsychiatric disorders associated with streptococcal infection).

Acute rheumatic fever is one of the main indications for antibiotic treatment of streptococcal pharyngitis.

 The following image shows strawberry tongue, also called raspberry tongue as seen in Scarlet fever:

questions.text: A patient presented to OPD with complaints of severe pain during erection and abnormal curvature of the penis for the last 6 months. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is indicative of Peyronie's disease.

Peyronie's disease is characterized by penile deformity, palpable penile plaques, erectile dysfunction, and pain on erection. It causes the penis to bend, usually towards the side of the plaque. It can be associated with Dupuytren's contracture as a part of the Galezia triad (Dupuytren's contracture, retroperitoneal fibrosis, Peyronie's disease).

Some cases may resolve spontaneously. If not, conservative measures such as oral tamoxifen, vitamin E, terfenadine, intralesional verapamil, etc. can be attempted. Intralesional collagenase has also been used. Penile extenders/ traction devices have also been used.

However, if none of these methods are effective, surgical management can be tried using Nesbit's procedure.

Nesbit's procedure is indicated when all other interventions have failed and the patient is experiencing difficulties in their sexual and personal life due to this condition. The procedure is started by creating an artificial erection by injecting normal saline.

Following this, an elliptical excision is done on the convex side of the penis (opposite to the thickened plaque). The width of the excised tissue depends on the degree of penile deformity. The side with the plaque is left as it is. 

Other options:

Marion's disease is a condition where hypertrophy of the internal sphincter leads to bladder outlet obstruction.

Priapism means persistent erection lasting longer than 4 hours and it is a surgical emergency (in case of ischemic priapism).

questions.text: What is the common type of degeneration seen in fibroids during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The common type of degeneration seen in fibroids during pregnancy is red degeneration.

Red degeneration is a complication of uterine myomas that develops most frequently during pregnancy. It is also seen in cases of painful fibroids in women older than 40 years. The myoma becomes tense and tender and causes severe abdominal pain with constitutional upset and fever. The fibroid assumes a peculiar purple-red colour and develops a fishy odour. Some of the large veins in the capsule and the small vessels in the substance of the tumour will be found thrombosed.

In calcareous degeneration, phosphates and carbonates of lime are deposited in the periphery along the course of the vessels. These are seen in old patients with long-standing fibroids. They are like womb- stones in graveyards.

 

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy

  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration

  • Red degeneration

  • Sarcomatous change

  • Torsion, hemorrhage

  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp

  • Inversion of the uterus

  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma

  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia

  • Accompanying adenomyosis

  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic alcoholic with a history of chronic liver disease presents to the emergency department with massive, sudden onset hematemesis. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic with sudden onset haematemesis is suggestive of esophageal variceal bleeding. 

The management of esophageal variceal bleeding involves:

  • Resuscitation with IV fluids, airway protection, and oxygen
  • Blood transfusion to maintain Hb between 7-9g/dL
  • Antibiotic prophylaxis with ceftriaxone before endoscopy
  • An attempt at hemostasis with octreotide or terlipressin or vasopressin
  • Upper GI endoscopy within 12 hours after fluid resuscitation to confirm the source of the bleed
  • Endoscopic variceal band ligation or sclerotherapy
  • In case, of failure or rebleeding - TIPS

Nonselective beta-blockers like propranolol and nadolol are used in the prophylaxis of variceal bleeding.

questions.text: A patient with a history of obstructed labor and cesarean section presents with continuous dribbling of urine through vagina on day 7. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of vesicovaginal fistula.

Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is a type of genital fistula, which is an abnormal communication between the genital tract and the urinary tract.

Vesicovaginal fistulae occur mostly due to obstetric injuries such as prolonged labor, and instrumental or manipulative deliveries. Patients present with true incontinence characterized by constant dribbling of urine. The presence of urine in the undergarments is uncomfortable and leads to pruritus and excoriation of the genital area

In obstructed labour, ischemia necrosis occurs as a result of prolonged compression effect on the bladder base between the head and symphysis pubis leading to infection → sloughing → fistula. Thus, it takes around 3–5 days following delivery to produce a fistula.

Clinical assessment by the introduction of a speculum helps to determine the size, number, and location of the fistulae. A methylene blue test helps confirm the diagnosis and determine the type of repair operation.

Small fistulas due to difficult childbirth can heal spontaneously. Most established fistulas need to be repaired vaginally usually after 3 months to allow the inflammation to subside.

The repair operation includes the Latzko procedure. The procedure involves denuding the vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges and approximating the raw surfaces. Another is the Chassar-Moir technique of widely separating the bladder and vagina and suturing them separately in two layers.

Post-operatively, continuous bladder drainage for 14 days along with antibiotics is recommended. Vaginal or speculum examination and intercourse are not advised for 3 months. Avoiding pregnancy for a year is also recommended. A cesarean section is usually done for future pregnancies.

Other options:

Option A: Vesicouterine fistula occurs during cesarean section or uterine rupture or placenta accreta. Patients complain of cyclical hematuria due to the trickling of menstrual blood into the bladder through this anomalous condition. But the urinary continence of the patient remains normal. This is also known as Youssef syndrome. 

Option B: In urethrovaginal fistulae, the patient is continent and dry, but may dribble urine during micturition. This usually follows surgery for a paravaginal cyst or urethral diverticulum, or after a penetrating injury from a fall or criminal abortion. The fistulous opening is visible on speculum examination.

Option C: Ureterovaginal fistulae result from direct injury to the ureter during gynecologic surgery (Eg: Wertheim's procedure for Ca cervix). Urine dribbles from both vagina and urethra post-surgery. The three-swab test will not stain with methylene blue, but with urine.

Related Pearl: Methylene blue - 3 swab test

Procedure:

A catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three (or four) sterile cotton swabs.

50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a catheter.

Results:

  • Upper swabs get wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter: Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Upper swabs get stained - the leak is from the bladder: Vesicovaginal fistula
  • Lower swabs get stained - the leak is from the urethra: Urethrovaginal fistula.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Abdominal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section
Clinical features

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is unable to micturate

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is able to micturate
Methylene blue 3-swab test Middle swab stains with methylene blue   Uppermost swab stains with urine, but not with methylene blue
Intravenous pyelography Normal Hydronephrosis and hydroureter present on the affected side

questions.text: The most common tumor of the parotid gland is ______.
questions.solution:
The most common tumor of the parotid gland is pleomorphic adenoma.

  • 80 to 90% of parotid gland tumors are benign; most commonly, they are pleomorphic adenomas.
  • Most commonly, they arise from the superficial lobe, and all tumors of the superficial lobe of the parotid gland should be managed by superficial parotidectomy.
  • Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the parotid gland.

Pleomorphic adenoma:

  • Slowly growing benign tumor
  • Unicentric in origin
  • Pseudo-capsule present
  • Potentially malignant
  • Possibility of protrusion of fringes of the tumor mass through the capsule
  • Radioresistant
  • Usually affects adults, females > males
  • Slowly growing, painless swelling
  • Well-defined margins
  • Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard consistency
  • Free from deeper structures
  • No facial nerve involvement
  • Deep lobe pushes tonsils and faucial pillars

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male patient came with complaints of lethargy, increased thirst, and increased frequency of urination for a few months. On examination, his BMI was 19 kg/m2 and laboratory investigation showed low levels of C-peptide, raised blood glucose, and absent ketone bodies. Anti-GAD antibodies were positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Anti-GAD: Antibodies to glutamic acid decarboxylase
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 32-year-old, thin-built male, presenting with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy with laboratory investigation showing low C-peptide, and positive anti-GAD antibodies are suggestive of latent autoimmune diabetes in adults (LADA). 

LADA is adult-onset diabetes with features of both type1 and type2 diabetes mellitus (DM). They phenotypically appear as type 2 but have autoantibodies like anti-GAD as in favor of type 1.

General characteristics of LADA are:

  • Age of onset more than 30 years
  • Family history of autoimmunity
  • Low or normal body mass index
  • Low C-peptide levels
  • Anti-GAD antibodies positive
  • Do not present with ketoacidosis initially due to the slow progression of beta-cell destruction

The diagnosis can be made based on three criteria as given by The Immunology of Diabetes Society

  • Adult age of onset (>30 years of age),
  • Positive circulating autoantibodies, and
  • No need for insulin treatment initially for several months after diagnosis

Initially, they don't require insulin but are more likely to be in insulin treatment within 5 years of onset. 

Other options:

Option A - Ketosis-prone type 2 diabetes patients are usually middle-aged men who are overweight and have a positive family history of diabetes. They have features similar to classic type 2 diabetes but often present with severe hyperglycemia and severe ketosis as in type 1 diabetes. Autoantibodies against beta-cell are negative in these patients. 

Option B: MODY or maturity-onset diabetes of the young is an autosomal dominant monogenic form of diabetes that occurs in less than 25 years of age. This is due to beta-cell dysfunction that impairs insulin secretion. The patients are non-ketotic and do not have pancreatic autoantibodies.

Option C: Type 1 diabetes mellitus most commonly develops before 20 years of age with most of them having evidence of islet-directed autoimmunity. Most of the patients present with hyperglycemia and ketoacidosis. There is increased lipolysis and ketone body production which results in muscle wasting, polyphagia, fatigue, and weakness.

Related Pearl: Comparative Features between MODY and Type 2 DM

 

Type 2 DM

MODY

Age of onset

Predominantly middle to old age

Predominantly young (< 25 years)

Pathology

Beta cell dysfunction

Insulin resistance

Only Beta cell dysfunction

No insulin resistance

Family history

Positive

Inheritance - Polygenic 

Vertical transmission through successive generations is not essential for diagnosis

Positive

Inheritance – Monogenic / Autosomal dominant 

Vertical transmission through at least two successive generation (ideally three) is essential for diagnosis

Insulin dependence

Non-insulin dependent

Non-insulin dependent

Obesity

Common

Uncommon

DKA

Uncommon

Uncommon

Serum insulin level

High
