questions.text: The characteristic finding on IVU as given below is seen in ________
questions.solution:
The given IVU shows a "drooping lily" sign which is seen in the duplex kidney (two separate pelvicalyceal systems draining single renal parenchyma). 

Duplex kidney:

The ureter draining the upper segment of the kidney inserts in the bladder inferior and medial to the ureter draining the lower segment of the kidney.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: Identify the segment marked in the image below.
questions.solution:
The liver segment highlighted in green in this CT section is segment V. The section of the CT given is taken below the portal vein as the cross-section of the portal vein before its bifurcation can be viewed.

A horizontal plane known as the portal plane divides the liver where the portal vein bifurcates and becomes horizontal. This divides each section of the liver into superior and inferior segments: 

  • Left lateral section: segment II above and segment III below the portal plane
  • Left medial section: segment IVa above and segment IVb below the portal plane
  • Right anterior (or medial) section: segment VIII above and segment V below the portal plane
  • Right posterior (or lateral) section: segment VII above and segment VI below the portal plane

 Shown below is a section from below the portal plane.

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver is divided into eight segments. It is based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the liver parenchyma. Each segment has its own vascular supply, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage.

The Couinaud's liver segments are as follows:

Related Pearl: Couinaud's Liver Segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text:
Match the following inborn errors of amino acid metabolism and their characteristic urine odours:
Inborn errors of metabolism Characteristic urine odours
1) Tyrosinemia a) Swimming pool
2) Phenylketonuria b) Tomcat urine
3) Multiple carboxylase deficiency c) Mousey
4) Hawkinsinuria d) Boiled cabbage
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-d,2-c,3-b,4-a.

  • Tyrosinemia - Boiled cabbage
  • Phenylketonuria - Mousey
  • Multiple carboxylase deficiency - Tomcat urine
  • Hawkinsinuria - Swimming pool

Tyrosinemia- Boiled cabbage odour may be present in tyrosinemia resulting from increased methionine metabolites (sulfur-containing compounds).

Phenylketonuria-It is due to deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of phenylalanine in the body fluids and the brain. The excess phenylalanine in the blood is metabolized to phenyl ketones,  namely, phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate, which are excreted in the urine, giving rise to the term phenylketonuria(PKU). Phenylacetate gives rise to the characteristic mousy odor in the urine in PKU.

Multiple carboxylase deficiencies lead to defects in the utilization of Biotin. Tomcat urine odor is characteristic. Affected infants should be treated with Biotin.

Hawkinsinuria- It is an autosomal-dominant condition caused by mutations in the gene for 4-HPPD. Swimming pool odor of the urine is characteristic of this condition.

questions.text: A postoperative patient comes for a follow-up visit to have his sutures removed. Which of the following blades will you use?
questions.solution:
A number-12 blade is used for suture removal.

A 12-size blade is a small, pointed, crescent-shaped blade used typically as a suture cutter. It is most sharp on the inside edge of its curve.

The number on a surgical blade communicates both its size and its shape. The different surgical blades are shown below:

Other options:

Option A: The 11-size blade has an oblique edge with a sharp-pointed tip and hence it is known as a "stab knife". 

Uses:

  • Commonly used to incise skin, subcutaneous tissue, and deep fascia to open the abscess cavity in a single stroke, during incision and drainage (I & D) of an abscess.
  • This blade can also be used for inserting drains and arteriotomy.

Option C: The 15-size blade has a narrow shaft and is often used for minor surgical procedures. 

Uses of 15-scalpel blade:

  • To make precise skin incisions in dermatosurgery
  • Minor surgical procedures
  • Select ocular procedures (15C blade)
  • Select plastic surgery procedures (15C blade)

Option D: The 10-size blade is used for skin incisions.

Note: The 22-size blade is often used for abdominal incisions. Essentially a larger version of the number 10, it has a flat, unsharpened back edge and a short, curved cutting edge. These blades are best for creating large incisions, often through thick skin. Surgical blades no. 20, 21, 22, 23, and 24 have a wide shaft and are used for larger incisions.

questions.text: The ECG of a pregnant lady having pre-eclampsia is shown below. Her vitals are stable. What is the best step in the management of the condition?
questions.solution:
The ECG of this patient points towards the diagnosis of torsades de pointes. Since the patient is hemodynamically stable, IV MgSO4 is the treatment of choice. 

IV MgSO4 is highly effective for both treatment and prevention of recurrence of long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that trigger torsades de pointes.

If the patient is hemodynamically unstable, then immediate defibrillation should be done.

Synchronized cardioversion Defibrillation

Used in VT and VF with a pulse

Also used in SVT, atrial flutter/fibrillation

 Used in VT and VF without a pulse
Shock delivered in sync with R wave (in absolute refractory period) Shock delivered at any time during cardiac cycle 

Monophasic: 100-200 J

Biphasic: 50-100 J

Monophasic: 360 J

Biphasic:1 20-200 J

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Revised Trauma Score ?
questions.solution:
Pulse rate is not a component of Revised Trauma Score.

Glasgow coma scale, Respiratory rate and Systolic BP are components of Revised Trauma Score (0-12).

Various scoring systems are used to score the trauma are :

  • AIS – Abbreviated Injury Scale
  • ISS – Injury Severity Score
  • OIS – Organ Injury Scale
  • GCS – Glasgow Coma Scale
  • RTS – Revised Trauma Score
  • MESS – Mangled Extremity Severity Score
  • TRISS – Trauma and Injury Severity Score

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
1-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

questions.text: A 30-year-old G2P1L1 woman is 18 weeks pregnant. She mentions that her previous labor was prolonged and tedious and eventually the doctor used an instrument to deliver her first child. Which of the following measurements would point towards the diagnosis of cephalo-pelvic disproportion at the pelvic inlet?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the diagnosis as cephalo-pelvic disproportion (CPD). Cephalo-pelvic disproportion at the pelvic inlet is diagnosed when the diagonal conjugate < 11.5 cm.

Disproportion with respect to the maternal pelvis is a state where the normal proportion between the size of the fetus to the size of the pelvis is disturbed. The disparity in the relation between the head and the pelvis is called cephalopelvic disproportion.

It can either occur due to an average size baby with a small pelvis or a relatively large baby with a normal pelvis. A history of prolonged or tedious labor, followed by either spontaneous or difficult instrumental delivery is suggestive of pelvic contraction. Difficult vaginal delivery ending in a stillborn or neonatal death without any etiological factor also suggests a contracted pelvis. Past history of fracture, rickets, osteomalacia, tuberculosis of the pelvic joints or spines, and poliomyelitis is elicited.

CPD can occur at the inlet, mid pelvis, or at the pelvic outlet. It is diagnosed at these levels by the following measurements.

  • Inlet CPD
    • Anteroposterior diameter < 10 cm
    • Diagonal conjugate < 11.5 cm
    • Transverse diameter < 12 cm.
  • Midpelvis CPD
    • Sum of the interspinous and posterior sagittal diameters of the mid pelvis </= 13.5 cm
    • Interspinous diameter < 8 cm
  • Outlet CPD
    • Interischial diameter </= 8 cm.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best specimen to diagnose congenital cytomegalovirus infection?

choices.text: Specimen of an organ such as liver, kidney

questions.solution:
Congenital CMV infection is diagnosed by detection of virus in the saliva or urine (saliva > urine), within the first two weeks of life. 

Congenital CMV infection occurs when a pregnant woman passes the cytomegalovirus to her unborn child. CMV is a common virus belonging to the herpesvirus family.

Congenital CMV infection can occur when a pregnant woman is infected with CMV for the first time (primary infection) or when she experiences reactivation or reinfection with a different strain of the virus during pregnancy. The virus can be transmitted to the fetus through the placenta.

The clinical manifestations are hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss.

Investigations:

  • Diagnosis can be made by the presence of IgM antibodies in the fetal blood. Isolation of the virus from the urine or blood by PCR is more sensitive.
  • If culture is required then urine samples are better than saliva.
  • PCR assays can be used to detect small amounts of CMV DNA in the urine.

There is no definitive treatment for congenital CMV infection. Treatment with ganciclovir is indicated only in patients with progressive neurologic disease and deafness.

questions.text: A woman recently became pregnant following a history of repeated abortions. She was anxious and wanted to undergo karyotyping this time to detect chromosomal disorders pre-natally. Barr body was found to be absent in her report. Which of the following is associated with an absent Barr body?
questions.solution:
Barr body is absent in female having 45 X0 genome.

Barr body

  • Densely staining inactivated condensed X chromosome present in each somatic cell of a female is found in the nucleus.
  • Chromatid body (Barr body or sex chromatin) is derived from one of the two X chromosomes which become inactivated.
  • The number of Barr bodies is thus one less than the number of X chromosomes.

Turner's syndrome is female without Barr body.

Klinefelter's syndrome is male with Barr body.

Note:

  • Lyon hypothesis states that only one of the two X chromosomes in a female is functional, the other becomes inactive during embryogenesis.
  • Davidson bodies are small nuclear buds of chromatin shaped like a drumstick found in neutrophils of females.

questions.text: Bupivacaine is used in epidural anesthesia for surgical anesthesia is at a concentration of
questions.solution:
The concentration of bupivacaine in epidural anesthesia for surgical anesthesia is at a concentration of 0.5%.

The dosage of local anesthetic in epidural anesthesia depends on the desired clinical effect. It can be used as:

  • Primary anesthetic for surgical anesthesia (sensory + motor block)
  • Combined with general anesthesia to supplement analgesia (sensory block)
  • Postoperative analgesia or labor analgesia (sensory block)
Various concentrations of Bupivacaine and its uses
Concentration Sensory block Motor block Clinical use
0.0625- 0.1% Analgesic None Labor analgesia (walking epidural)
0.1-0.25% Analgesic Minimal Postoperative analgesia
0.5-0.75% Dense Moderate to dense Surgical anesthesia

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented with symptoms of food impaction, dysphagia, and a burning sensation in his chest. Based on the barium swallow image given below, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium swallow image showing the feline esophagus sign are suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis.

Eosinophilic esophagitis is an idiopathic condition commonly affecting the proximal 1/3rd of the esophagus. Eosinophils migrate to the esophagus and contribute to extensive tissue damage and inflammation.  

Clinical features include difficulty in swallowing, food impaction, vomiting, heartburn, and symptoms similar to those of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Non-responsiveness to proton-pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy is often seen. 

Barium swallow shows the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus. These rings appear similar to stripes on a cat, and the appearance is referred to as the feline esophagus sign. It is thought to be due to contraction of the muscularis mucosae, with the resultant shortening of the esophagus and bunching up of the mucosa in the lumen.

On endoscopy, the esophagus appears narrow and friable with transient or fixed mucosal rings, strictures, and linear furrows. 

The diagnosis requires a biopsy with a histologic finding of >15–20 eosinophils per high-power field. An exclusion diet and steroids help in the management of this condition.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect. 

Related Pearl: Endoscopic Findings in Esophagitis

 

Conditions Endoscopic findings
Infectious esophagitis Diffuse and involve the proximal esophagus  
HSV esophagitis Vesicles and small punched-out lesions (volcano ulcers)
CMV esophagitis Serpiginous ulcers
Peptic esophagitis Solitary and distal  
Eosinophilic esophagitis Multiple esophageal rings, linear furrows, or white punctate exudates (feline esophagus)
Pill esophagitis Singular and deep at points of luminal narrowing with sparing of the distal esophagus
Candida esophagitis White friable plaques, in advance form - adherent, grey-white pseudomembranes.

 

The image below shows the lesions of CMV esophagitis.

The image below shows the lesions of candida esophagitis.

The image below shows feline esophagus in eosinophilic esophagitis.

The image below shows the erosive lesion of pill esophagitis.

The image below shows the lesions of HSV esophagitis.

questions.text: A young patient presents with distension of the abdomen and yellowish discoloration of the eyes for the past 6 months.  After a detailed workup, he is diagnosed with early-stage hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lobe of the liver. The surgeon decides to perform a left hemi-hepatectomy. Which of the following segments has to be removed in the patient?
questions.solution:
In the left hemi-hepatectomy (also called left hepatectomy) the segments marked as II, III, and IV should be removed.

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver is divided into eight segments. Each segment has its own vascular supply, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage. Segment I corresponds to the caudate lobe of the liver and segment IV corresponds to the quadrate lobe of the liver. 

The Couinaud's Liver Segments are as follows:

questions.text: True about hemolytic uremic syndrome(HUS) is all except

choices.text: Symptoms and signs of HUS develops as diarrhea begins to improve
Only supportive managment of acute renal failure is done in typical HUS
Eculizumab improves MAHA( microangiopathic hemolytic anemia) picture in atypical HUS
Anemia in HUS is  Coomb's test positive

questions.solution:
Anaemia in HUS is Coomb's test negative (Because Coomb's test is positive in antibody-mediated hemolysis and hemolysis in HUS is due to mechanical obstruction to flow of RBCs due to microthrombi)

Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome:

Typical HUS

  • Usually follows diarrheal illness 
  • The most common cause worldwide is E.coli O157: H7
  • A most common cause in India is shigella dysentriae type I
  • Pathogenesis: Shiga-like toxin causes endothelial damage which leads to platelet activation and adhesion and ultimately forming platelet thrombi.
  • Treatment: No specific treatment is present. Only supportive management of acute renal failure.

Atypical HUS

  • It is due to uncontrolled activation of the complement system because of mutation in genes encoding complement regulatory proteins e.g complement factor H
  • Standard treatment in atypical HUS is plasma exchange which provides a deficient regulator.
  • Eculizumab - C5 inhibitor (prevents the pro-inflammatory effect of terminal complement activation).

questions.text: A young male patient with a history of a respiratory tract infection 4 weeks ago presents with progressively increasing weakness and tingling of bilateral lower limbs. His upper limbs are not affected and on examination, there is an absent knee jerk. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is Guillain Barre (GB) syndrome.

Guillain-Barre syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by ascending motor paralysis. Patients present with symptoms such as:

  • Progressive ascending motor paralysis
  • Areflexia. Deep tendon reflexes disappear within the first few days of symptoms
  • Tingling sensation
  • Facial paresis may be seen in certain cases

It is estimated that 70% of cases of GB syndrome occur following an acute infection, usually respiratory or gastrointestinal.

High-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis are equally effective for typical GBS. IVIg is the initial therapy chosen because of its ease of administration and good safety record.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  1. B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.
  2. Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM
  3. The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.
  4. Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.
  5. The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.
  6. These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

questions.text: The type of laryngoscope blade shown in the given image is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Miller laryngoscopic blade. 

A laryngoscope is an instrument used for examination of the larynx and facilitation of tracheal intubation. It has three components: the handle, the blade, and the light source. The Macintosh and Miller blades are the most popularly used blades.

Miller's blade is a straight blade. Its curve begins 2 inches from the tip. It is inserted using the para-glossal technique. This technique avoids contact with the maxillary incisors and provides maximal tongue control.

It is used in:

  • Neonates, infants, and young children
  • Adults with short thyromental distance and long floppy epiglottis.

Macintosh blade is a sharply curved blade with a large flange. It is inserted in the right side of the mouth, and the flange is used to sweep the tongue to the left. The blade is advanced and positioned in the vallecula. Advantages of a curved blade include:

  • Greater room available for the passage for an endotracheal tube
  • Less damage to the teeth

questions.text: An 18 year old girl presents with a history of low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain and amenorrhoea for six months. On examination, a pelvic mass is felt on the left side and signs of ascites are positive. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This female with a 6 months chronic history of symptoms along with the presence of a palpable abdominopelvic mass suggests genital tuberculosis. 

Genital tuberculosis commonly affects women in the reproductive age group. It presents with menstrual irregularities such as amenorrhoea, menorrhagia, dysmenorrhoea, pelvic pain. Non specific symptoms like fever and weight loss are also present. It affects fallopian tube causing infertility, tubo-ovarian masses, hydrosalpinx, pyosalpinx. Pelvic and abdominal peritoneum is often involved with multiple tubercles, ascites and abdominal masses.

Other options:

Option A: Submucous fibroid presents with menorrhagia, dyspareunia, pelvic pain, infertility or recurrent pregnancy loss.

Option B: Ovarian malignancy can also present with symptoms like abdominal fullness, bloating, nausea, abdominal distention, early satiety, fatigue, change in bowel movements, urinary symptoms, back pain, dyspareunia, weight loss, palpable pelvic mass or ascites . But this patient's young age and a chronic course of 6 month is unlikely to be a malignancy.

Option C: Ectopic pregnancy presents as amenorrhoea followed by an acute symptoms of vaginal bleeding and pelvic pain in a reproductive age women. It does not have a long course of 6 months and other symptoms seen in this girl.

questions.text: Given below are the four causes of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) with the corresponding class of a PALM-COEIN classification. Which is incorrect?
questions.solution:
The polycystic ovarian disease is an ovarian cause of abnormal uterine bleeding which comes under AUB-O, in the PALM-COEIN classification.

AUB in the reproductive age group was previously known as dysfunctional uterine bleeding, however, that term is now obsolete. AUB can be acute or chronic:

  • Acute AUB - it can start sporadically or be superimposed on chronic AUB.
  • Chronic AUB - it lasts for 6 months (3 months minimum).

PALM-COEIN classification of AUB:

  • Polyp (AUB-P):
    • Endometrial polyps
    • Endocervical polyps
  • Adenomyosis (AUB-A)
  • Leiomyoma (AUB-L). Fibroids are further classified as:
    • Submucosal (SM)
    • Other (O)
  • Malignancy and hyperplasia (AUB-M) 
    • Endometrial hyperplasia 
    • Endometrial carcinoma
  • Coagulopathy (AUB-C)
    • von Willebrand's disease
    • Hemophilias
  • Ovarian causes (AUB-O)
    • PCOD
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Hyperprolactinemia.  
  • Endometrial causes (AUB-E)
    • Tubercular or chlamydial endometritis 
  • Iatrogenic causes (AUB-I)
    • Intrauterine contraceptive devices
    • Anticoagulants
    • Tricyclic antidepressants
  • Not yet classified (AUB-N) includes rare causes such as
    • Arteriovenous malformations 
    • Myometrial hypertrophy

questions.text: A neonate was noted to have cyanosis of the oral mucosa. Chest x-ray revealed a snowman appearance of the cardiac silhouette. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Snowman's appearance on the chest X-ray image is classically seen in total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC).

Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection/return is a cyanotic congenital heart disease in which the pulmonary veins fail to make their normal connection with the left atrium. This results in anomalous drainage into the systemic circulation.

There are four types of TAPVC based on the level of connections relative to the heart. The four types are:

  • Supracardiac
  • Cardiac
  • Infracardiac
  • Mixed

The supracardiac variant can classically depict a snowman appearance/figure of 8/cottage loaf heart on the frontal chest radiograph.

The dilated vertical vein on the left, the brachiocephalic vein on the top, and the superior vena cava on the right form the head of the snowman; the body of the snowman is formed by the enlarged right atrium. The image given below shows a snowman or figure-8 configuration. Cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary vascularity are evident.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or Figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: The correct match is ______.
questions.solution:
• Lead-pipe/egg-shell calcification is seen in traumatic fat necrosis.
  • Popcorn calcification is seen in fibroadenoma.
  • Broken-needle type of calcification is seen in duct ectasia.
  • Tea-cup calcification is seen in fibrocystic disease.

Popcorn calcification:

 

Lead-pipe/egg-shell calcification

 

 

Broken-needle type of calcification 

 

 

Tea-cup calcification-On a lateral magnification view, layering of calcific fluid contained within microcysts can be appreciated, producing a characteristic ‘teacup’ appearance.

questions.text: A multigravida woman in the labor room presents with uncontrolled bleeding after delivery of the placenta. What is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage(PPH)?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage is atonic uterus. Uterine atony is responsible for at least 80% of cases of PPH.

Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery. This ineffective uterine contraction prevents mechanical hemostasis from occurring and leads to uncontrollable bleeding from the placental implantation site.

Postpartum hemorrhage is defined as a loss of more than 500 ml of blood after the completion of the third stage of labor (in vaginal delivery). PPH is blood loss of more than 1000 mL from the genital tract following a cesarean section.

Depending upon the amount of blood loss, PPH can be, minor (<1L) or major (>1L). Major is further subdivided into moderate (1L-2L) and severe (>2L).

Types of PPH:

Primary/early PPH: Hemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. Causes include

  • Atony: Primi, grand multipara, over distended uterus, hydramnios, precipitate labor, prolonged labor, uterine malformations, fibroid uterus
  • Trauma: Instrumental deliveries, episiotomy, precipitate labor, macrosomia
  • Retained tissues: retained placenta, blood clots
  • Bleeding disorders: Sepsis, Intrauterine death, HELLP syndrome.

Secondary/ late PPH: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum. Causes include 

  • Placental polyp: Retained products undergo necrosis with fibrin deposition and eventually form a placental polyp, which on detachment from the myometrium causes brisk hemorrhage.
  • Abnormal involution of the placental site.
  • Retention of placental cotyledon or products of conception.
  • Uterine artery pseudoaneurysm.
  • Endometritis
  • Coagulopathy

questions.text: The following set of instruments are used for which procedure?
questions.solution:
The given set of instruments are commonly used for the collection of pap smears. The given image includes Cusco's bivalved self-retaining speculum, Koplin's jar, smear slides, Ayer's spatula, and endocervical brush. 

Pap/ Papanicolaou test is a screening test only. The presence of abnormal cells/ a positive test requires further evaluation by colposcopy, cervical biopsy, or fractional curettage.

Prerequisites:

  • Should be done prior to vaginal examination.
  • Lubricants should not be used.
  • The patient should not be menstruating during the pap test.
  • The ideal time is around ovulation.
  • The patient should not have had intercourse in the 24hrs prior to the test.

Screening guidelines:

  • Time for initiation: 21 years, regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse.
  • Women aged 21-29 years: Every 3 years(earlier it was done annually)
  • Women who are aged 30-65 years: Pap test + HPV testing every 5 years.
  • Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If suspicious PAP, screening till 75 years.
  • HIV+ women: annual checkup until three consecutive negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life.
  • HPV DNA testing in combination with PAP improves the sensitivity of screening.

Ayres spatula and endocervical brush are the instruments used for the pap test.

 

 

Hysteroscopy is the process of inspection of the uterine cavity. 

Indications:

Diagnostic:

  • Endocervical study in suspected endocervical malignancy, preinvasive cancer, and biopsy
  • Uterus—malformations, endometrial TB, Asherman syndrome, misplaced IUCD, menorrhagia, intermenstrual, bleeding submucous fibroid, polyp
  • Falloscopy

Therapeutic:

  • Endometrial polypectomy
  • Submucous fibroid
  • Septate uterus
  • Asherman syndrome
  • Removal of IUCD
  • Tubal sterilization
  • Balloonoplasty
  • IVF Intrafallopian insemination

The image shows the procedure of hysteroscopy and the common instruments used for the same.

 

Biopsy:

To take biopsy we commonly use Gellhorn's punch biopsy forceps as shown in the image below. It is used to take biopsies from the cervix.

 

Dilatation and curettage:

Instruments used in D&C:

  • Sim’s speculum: It retracts the posterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix
  • Anterior vaginal wall retractor: Retracts the anterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix.
  • Vulsellum or Allis forceps: To hold the anterior lip of the cervix
  • Uterine sound: Simpson's uterine sound is a 30 cm long angulated instrument with a handle at one end and a rounded blunt tip at the other.
    It is used to measure the length of the uterus. It can be identified by the markings used for measurement
  • Cervical dilators: 
    • Hegar's dilator is a double-ended dilator used to dilate the cervix.
    • Hawkins’ single-ended dilator 
    • Fenton’s dilator
  • Curette:
    • Sim's curette is a single-ended curette
    • Blake's curette is a double-ended curette

 

The image above shows the trolley with various instruments:

  1. Sim's uterine curette
  2. Hegars dilator
  3. Sim's uterine sound
  4. Karman's cannula - It is used for menstrual regulation. It can be identified by the whistle-like tip.
  5. Leech Wilkinson's cannula
  6. Rubin's cannula 

Leech Wilkinson's cannula and Rubin's cannula are used in hysterosalpingography.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes. All of the following findings may be responsible for the given symptoms except:
questions.solution:
Bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes is suggestive of cyanosis. Cyanosis is not seen when reduced hemoglobin is 2 gm%, it becomes apparent when the concentration of reduced hemoglobin exceeds 4 gm/dL.

Cyanosis is detectable with methemoglobin ≥ 1.5 gm% and/or sulfhemoglobin ≥ 0.5 gm%.

Central cyanosis is detectable when the oxygen saturation falls to 85%. In dark-skinned people, it may be detectable at the oxygen saturation of 75%.

The types of cyanosis are:

Central cyanosis Peripheral cyanosis

Due to diminished arterial oxygen saturation/presence of abnormal hemoglobin derivative.

Due to diminished peripheral blood flow.

Mucous membranes and skin are both affected

 Mucous membranes of the oral cavity or those beneath the tongue are spared.

Decreases after O2 supplementation

 Does not decrease after O2 supplementation

questions.text: An HIV-positive individual presents with the following. What is the diagnosis &  WHO clinical stage of HIV?
questions.solution:
Oral candidiasis (Thrush) is characterized in WHO Clinical Stage 3.

Oral Candidiasis (Thrush), and oral hairy leukoplakia, are oral lesions characterized in WHO clinical Stage 3. They generally occur in patients with CD4+ T cell counts of <300/μL.

Differentiating oral candidiasis and oral hairy leukoplakia:

  • Oral Candidiasis (Thrush) appears as a white, cheesy exudate, on an erythematous mucosa in the posterior oropharynx. The diagnosis is made by direct examination of pseudohyphal elements.
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia presents as white, frondlike lesions, generally along the lateral borders of the tongue and sometimes on the adjacent buccal mucosa(image below). Despite its name, oral hairy leukoplakia is not considered premalignant. Lesions are associated with Ebstein barr virus (EBV).

questions.text: The image shown below shows the technique of insertion of which of the following devices
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the technique of insertion of the laryngeal mask airway.

The laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device that is positioned in the hypopharynx.

Supraglottic airway devices are used with both spontaneously and mechanically ventilated patients during anaesthesia.

LMA has the advantages of being used in many settings, including the operating room (alternate route of ventilation), the emergency department (difficult intubation), and out-of-hospital care (paramedics).

This is because it is easy to use, quick to place even for inexperienced providers, and has a very high success rate.

The technique of insertion:

  • The deflated cuff of LMA is lubricated and inserted blindly into the hypopharynx. Once inflated, the cuff forms a low-pressure seal around the entrance to the larynx.
  • Correct placement of the tube is confirmed by giving gentle positive pressure ventilation while checking for chest rise and ETCO2 using capnography.

Other options:

Option A: Oropharyngeal airway is inserted in the patient’s mouth with concavity towards the hard palate. As the airway is inserted it is rotated 180 degrees (concavity towards the tongue) until the flange comes to rest on the patient’s lips. 

Option B: Nasopharyngeal airway is inserted through the nostril (after lubrication) along the natural curvature of the floor of the nasal cavity with the bevel pointing towards the septum. Once the device is inserted the flange should rest on the nostril opening.

Option D: Endotracheal tube is inserted infraglottically after visualizing the vocal cords with direct laryngoscopy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old nulliparous woman presented with mild dyspareunia. Examination revealed a non-tender, mobile, fluctuant swelling on the vaginal wall. Ultrasound examination revealed a single cyst of size approximately 2 cm, independent from the bowel and bladder. The cyst arises from the part in the image labeled as A. Structure A is a remnant of what?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a case of a Gartner's duct cyst, which develops from the Gartner's duct (marked as A), a remnant of the mesonephric duct (Wolffian duct). 

The remnants of Wolffian ducts (Gartner's duct) in females are located in the broad ligament and vagina. It is an imperfect duct that runs below and parallel to the fallopian tube in the mesosalpinx. The duct passes downwards by the side of the uterus until the internal os, after which it passes into the cervix. It then runs forwards, reaching the anterolateral part of the vaginal wall.

Gartner's duct cysts are located in the vagina or broad ligament. They are usually asymptomatic and found within the lateral vaginal wall during a routine examination. Symptoms if present, might include dyspareunia, pain, and difficulty inserting tampons. Examination reveals a tense cyst, seen bulging from beneath the vaginal wall.

Differentials include epidermoid cysts, Bartholin's gland cyst, uterine prolapse, cystocele, rectocele, urethral diverticula.

Treatment is observation in most cases. Marsupialization or excision may be done if large and symptomatic.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman complains of difficulty swallowing for the past few months. She also complains of bluish discoloration of fingers on exposure to cold for the past 5 years. On examination, she is found to have thickening of the skin of the hands and multiple dilated capillaries over the face. Which of the following is most specific for this disease?
questions.solution:
Anti-centromere antibodies are most specific for this disease.

This patient's clinical features are suggestive of CREST syndrome / Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

CREST syndrome consists of :

  • Calcinosis cutis
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Esophageal dysmotility
  • Sclerodactyly
  • Telangiectasia

Systemic sclerosis is a chronic autoimmune disease. Progressive fibrosis due to the deposition of extracellular matrix components in different tissues and organs is the prominent feature.

The characteristic features of systemic sclerosis are vascular damage, inflammation, and the presence of specific autoantibodies. 

Systemic sclerosis is classified into two based on the extent of skin involvement.

  • Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis / CREST syndrome
  • Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis

In limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), fibrosis in the skin of acral parts of the body, like the face and limbs (distal to elbow and knee) takes place. Skin fibrosis in limited type has a slow progression but microcirculation disturbances like Raynaud's phenomenon start long before the skin symptoms and are associated with the involvement of the lungs and esophagus. 

Since it has late and slow organ involvement, it is associated with a good prognosis with a 10-year survival of over 90%. 

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are present in 90 - 95% of cases with SSc.

Autoantibodies specific to limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis include,

  • Anti- centromere
  • Anti-Th/To
  • Anti-U1-RNP
  • Anti-hUBF

Management is based on disease-modifying and organ-specific drugs. For peripheral vasculopathy and digital ulcers, calcium channel blockers like nifedipine, amlodipine is used and for refractory cases, phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors are recommended.

Intravenous prostanoids are used for the healing process of digital ulcers and the improvement of microcirculation. The commonly used immunosuppressants for skin fibrosis are methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and mycophenolate mofetil. When these drugs are ineffective or contraindicated, low-dose glucocorticosteroids or rituximab (anti-CD20) are used. 

Related Pearl: Autoantibodies Seen in Autoimmune Diseases

         Autoantibody Associated disease
Antinuclear (ANA)

SLE (non-specific)
Anticardiolipin lupus anticoagulant SLE, APLA syndrome
Anti-ds DNA, anti-smith SLE
Anti-histone Drug-induced Lupus
Anti-U1 RNP Mixed connective tissue disease
Rheumatoid factor, anti-CCP Rheumatoid arthritis
Anti-Ro/SSA, Anti-La/SSB Sjögren’s syndrome
Anti-Scl-70 (anti-DNA topoisomerase) Diffuse scleroderma
Anticentromere CREST syndrome
Anti-SRP, Anti-Mi-2, Anti-Jo-1 Polymyositis, Dermatomyositis
p-ANCA/MPO Churg Strauss syndrome
c-ANCA Wegener (Granulomatosis with polyangiitis)

questions.text: The plot obtained from a meta-analysis study is given below. Which of the following represents the x-axis?
questions.solution:
The image shown is of a symmetric funnel plot. The x-axis represents the outcome, usually the odds ratio and the  y-axis is usually the standard error or another estimate of precision.

Other options:

Line of no effect and confidence interval are seen in a forest plot.

The vertical solid line - the “line of no effect", which represents the odds ratio or relative risk. If it is the odds ratio, then the vertical line would be at 1. No difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1). 

The horizontal line on either side is the confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results

questions.text: CT done for a patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of sterile pyuria with CT showing right-sided putty kidney points to renal tuberculosis. 

Putty kidney refers to the amorphous dystrophic calcification seen over the entire kidney during the end stage of genitourinary TB. 

Genitourinary tuberculosis is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream. It occurs either due to reinfection or reactivation of old TB.

CT is the most sensitive modality and is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications. CT urography is done to assess the various stages of renal TB. 

ATT is given to all patients with genitourinary TB. Nephrectomy is the preferred treatment in patients with putty/ cement kidneys.

Option D: Nephrocalcinosis refers to the deposition of calcium salts in the kidney parenchyma and tubules.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly in newborn?
questions.solution: Aqueductal stenosis is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly (enlargement of ventricles of brain) in newborn.

questions.text: Identify the congenital anomaly show in the MRI image:
questions.solution:
The given Axial T1 weighted image demonstrates the typical figure of eight sign consistent with a neonate with lissencephaly.

Lissencephaly represents a group of disorders caused by defective neuronal migration in the period between the 8th and 14th gestational weeks, resulting in a lack of development of gyri and sulci.

Other options: Holoprosencephaly is a developmental disorder of the brain that results from the defective formation of the prosencephalon and inadequate induction of forebrain structures.

Figure of Eight (8) sign in Lissencephaly (as shown below).

questions.text: During genetic counseling, a pregnant woman states that both she and her husband have sickle cell trait. You offer the option of chorionic villus sampling for prenatal diagnosis. What is the best time to perform this procedure?
questions.solution:
The best time to perform chorionic villous sampling is 11-13 weeks.

Chorionic villus sampling:
Study material

Chorionic villi from trophoblastic cells

Time

10 to 13 weeks (transcervically)

10 weeks to term (transabdominally)

Indications

To detect chromosomal abnormalities such as Down syndrome.

To detect inborn errors of metabolism like phenylketonuria.

For DNA analysis in hemoglobinopathies, thalassemia, and sickle cell anemia.
Complications

Abortion (CVS> Amniocentesis)

Limb reduction defects and oro-mandibular defects (when done before 10 weeks)
Drawback

Not suitable for the detection of neural tube defects.

questions.text: Which nerve is involved in Frey’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
The auriculotemporal nerve (V3 nerve) is involved in Frey's syndrome.

Frey’s syndrome is also known as Dupuy syndrome or auriculotemporal syndrome. It commonly develops post parotid surgery or other surgeries that cause an opening of the parotid capsule. It is caused by an aberrant regeneration of post-ganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibres, along the sympathetic pathways to the sweat glands near the parotid region. 

Clinical features as a result of salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food include:

  • Sweating
  • Warmth
  • Redness of the face 

Diagnosed using a starch-iodine test. Denervation by a tympanic neurectomy or auriculotemporal nerve avulsion has been advocated in management but is often not curative. The symptoms can be managed by the subcutaneous infiltration of purified botulinum toxin into the affected area and the use of antiperspirant.

Related Pearl: Parasympathetic/ secretomotor (general visceral efferent) innervation of glands

  • Nervus intermedius, also called the nerve of Wrisberg, is the sensory & secretomotor component of the facial nerve.
  • The main trunk of the facial nerve, as it exits the brainstem, only carries motor fibers.

questions.text:
Match the following:
  1. First-degree heart block
  2. Mobitz type 1 heart block
  3. Mobitz type 2 heart block
  4. Complete heart block
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are 1- c, 2- a, 3- d, and 4- b.

The different types of heart blocks are:

First Degree Heart Block: It occurs due to slowing of conduction through the AV junction. It is characterized by prolonged PR > 0.2s and equal RR intervals.

 

Second Degree Heart Block: It occurs due to the intermittent failure of electrical impulse conduction from the atrium to the ventricle. It is characterized by a missed QRS. It is of two types:

  • Mobitz type 1/ Wenckebach occurs due to the decremental conduction of electrical impulses in the AV node. It is characterized by a progressive PR elongation leading to an eventual drop in the QRS complex. This may be seen in young athletes.

 

  • Mobitz type 2 occurs in the distal or infra-His conduction system and is often associated with intraventricular conduction delays.  It is characterized by an intermittent failure of conduction of the p wave without any change in the preceding impulses. On ECG there is a fixed PR interval and missed QRS.

 

Third Degree Heart Block/Complete Heart Block

It occurs when none of the impulses from the atria are conducted to the ventricles. It is characterized by

  • Escape rhythm
  • RR equal, PP equal
  • P waves > QRS waves
  • No relationship between P & QRS

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

questions.text: In the experiment shown below, what role does the whistle play?
questions.solution:
The experiment shown in the image is that of classical conditioning by Ivan Pavlov. The whistle plays the role of a conditional stimulus.

Classical conditioning is the theory of learning where a neutral stimuli is associated with a psychologically significant event.

Events in the Pavlov experiment:

  • Food - Unconditional stimulus as it elicits salivation before the experiment commences
  • Response to food - Salivation as a result of the unconditional stimulus is the unconditional response as it is elicited before the commencement of the experiment.
  • Bell/Whistle - Conditional stimulus as it elicits salivation conditional to the pairing of the bell and food
  • Response to the bell/whistle - This is known as the conditional response as the dog has been conditioned to react to the conditional stimulus.

This model usually deals with involuntary responses. It is also called learning by association or respondent conditioning. He's also known for his work on the physiology of digestion

The image below shows the steps of Pavlov's classical conditioning experiment:

questions.text: The method shown in the image is:
questions.solution:
The image shows marshall burns technique used in the delivery of aftercoming head in breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Baby is allowed to hang by its own weight till the nape of neck is visible
  • When the nape of neck is visible under the pubic arch, baby is grasped by the ankles
  • Baby is swung in an arc in an upward and forward direction towards the mother's abdomen

Other Options: 
Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.
Pinard’s maneuver used for delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.
Ritgen maneuver is used for controlled delivery of head in normal labor.

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV-positive male has been diagnosed with Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PCP). Primary prophylaxis for this condition is recommended to be started at CD4 T cell % of ______
questions.solution:
Primary prophylaxis for Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PCP) in HIV positive individuals is recommended to be started at CD4 % <15% or CD+ T cell count of <200 /ul.

Primary Prophylaxis of PCP

  • Indications: CD4+ T cell count <200/uL ( CD4 cell %<15), recent oropharyngeal candidiasis and prior PCP.
  • Drug of choice is Trimethoprim/Sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX)
  • Alternatives – Dapsone/Pyrimethamine + Leucovorin or Atovaqone or Aerosolised Pentamidine

questions.text: A patient was brought following a road traffic accident. His pulse rate was 120 bpm, BP 80/40 mmHg, and the extremities were cold. Which of the given peripheral cannulas will you use during the resuscitation of this patient?
questions.solution:
For trauma patients who necessitate a high volume of fluid replacement and multiple blood transfers large-sized, wide-bored cannulas are preferred. Among the given options, an 18G size (green) cannula would be appropriate (larger cannulae have a smaller gauge number).

In the above image, the cannulae numbered 1 to 4 are respectively:

  1. 18G - green
  2. 20G - pink
  3. 22G - blue
  4. 24G - yellow

Hypovolemic shock is frequently caused by hemorrhage which can be external due to trauma or internal. The most common cause of internal hemorrhage leading to hypovolemic shock is gastrointestinal bleeding. Massive burns and vomiting are other causes of hypovolemic shock. 

The goal of care in this scenario is to improve volume status which can be done through the placement of large-bore intravenous lines (16 gauge or 18 gauge) and administering fluids.

Related Pearl: Color Coding of Intravenous Cannulae

questions.text: A 7-month-old child is brought to the outpatient department with a deformity as shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the preferred first-line conservative management?
questions.solution:
The first line of conservative management of the condition in the given image, congenital talipes equino varus deformity (CTEV), is manipulation and cast by Ponsetti's method.

CTEV is a congenital deformity of the foot. In a full-blown deformity, the foot is in equinus, the entire hindfoot is in varus and the mid and forefoot are adducted and supinated. Clinically this appears as a foot that's twisted and turned inwards.

In patients with CTEV, the skin and soft tissues of the calf and the medial side of the foot are underdeveloped. If CTEV is not managed appropriately then these changes become permanent.

The first line of conservative management in a child with CTEV is Ponsetti's method. In this method, the three main deformities of CTEV are collected in the following order.

  • Cavus - The first metatarsal is elevated to create a flat longitudinal medial border of the foot.
  • Adduction- The forefoot is abducted in the plane of the metatarsals which rotates and everts the hindfoot and corrects the forefoot out of supination
  • Equinus is corrected by dorsiflexing the foot at the ankle joint. 

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Head circumference equals chest circumference by 9-12 months.
Birth weight doubles by 2 years and quadruples by 5 years of age.
Newborns typically regain their birth weight within 24 hours after birth.
Head circumference should be measured within 24 hours after birth.

questions.solution:
Head circumference equals chest circumference by 9-12 months.

In newborns:

  • Head circumference increases rapidly during the first year of life and is generally greater than chest circumference at birth.
  • By 9-12 months of age, head circumference typically equals chest circumference.
  • After 1 year, chest circumference tends to exceed head circumference.
  • It's important to measure head circumference accurately using the cross-tape method.
  • Head circumference should not be measured within 24 hours after birth due to molding during delivery, which can affect accuracy.
  • Birth weight typically doubles by 5 months and quadruples by 2 years of age, reflecting rapid growth and development in infancy.

 

Related Pearl: Weight and height changes in children

Term newborns may lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the first few days of life (due to extracellular fluid losses). Most healthy newborns typically regain their birth weight by 10 to 14 days. Thereafter, approximate daily weight gain is as follows :

  • 0-3 months ~ 30 grams/day
  • 3-6 months ~ 20 grams/day
  • 6-12months ~ 12-15 grams/day

Weight gained with respect to birth weight

Age Weight
5 months 2 × birth weight
1 year 3 × birth weight
2 years 4 × birth weight
3 years 5 × birth weight

Formulae for calculating the weight in children

Age Formula
3-12 months
Weight =[age (months) + 9]
2
1-6 years Weight = [2×age (years)] + 8
7-12 years
Weight = [7×age (years) - 5]
2

Height with respect to age

Age Height
At birth 50 cm
6 months 65 cm
1 year 75 cm
2 years 90 cm
4 years 100 cm

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a lump in her right breast was advised to undergo mammography which was reported as BIRADS 3. What will be the appropriate next step of management in this patient?
questions.solution:
A BIRADS score of 3 means that it is probably a benign lesion. The next appropriate step is to follow up with this patient every 6 months for the next 2 years.

During this period, the score can either downgrade to BIRADS 2 or upgrade to BIRADS 4 or 5.

Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) standardizes the reporting for mammography and ultrasonography and helps guide decision making:

Category Definition Follow-up
0 Incomplete assessment Additional imaging evaluation
1 Negative Annual screening
2 Benign finding Annual screening
3 Probably benign finding 6 monthly mammogram for next 2 years
4 Suspicious abnormality (2%-95% malignant) Biopsy
5 Highly suggestive of malignancy (>95% malignant) Appropriate action should be taken 
6 Known biopsy—proven malignancy Appropriate treatment

questions.text: The arthropod shown in the image is not a vector for which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
The arthropod shown in the image is a rat flea which is not a vector for Scrub typhus.

Rat fleas are vectors for:

  • Endemic typhus
  • Bubonic plague
  • Hymenolepis diminuta

Rat fleas are wingless, their head is conical in shape and is directly attached to the thorax without a neck. The head has piercing mouth parts that are conspicuous and project downward for sucking blood. They have 3 pairs of legs attached to the thorax. 

The type of zoonosis is meta-zoonosis, and the type of biological transmission is the propagative transmission. In propagative biological transmission, the disease agent only multiplies in the vector but there is no change in form. Metazoonosis refers to zoonoses that require both vertebrates and invertebrates to complete their infectious cycle.

Endemic typhus is caused by R. typhi. Rats are the reservoirs of infection and the parasite is transmitted by Xenopsylla cheopis (flea). The infection is transmitted when the flea faeces are rubbed into the bite wound. Patients can present with fever, headache, myalgia, and rash.

Bubonic plague is caused by Yersinia pestis through the bite of infected rat fleas and presents as inguinal buboes. Other types of plague include pneumonic and septicemic plague which are less common than bubonic plague.

Fleas transmit these diseases through the bite of a blocked flea, defecation, or direct mechanical transmission. Control of the disease is done by using insecticides such as 10% DDT, repellents like diethyltoluamide, and rodent control.

Scrub typhus is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by trombiculid mites. The incubation period is 1-3 weeks. The patient typically develops a characteristic eschar which is a punched-out ulcer covered with a blackened scab at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. 

The below image shows the trombiculid mite which is responsible for the transmission of Orientia tsutsugamushi.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text: Bubonocele is a type of _________.
questions.solution:
Bubonocele is a type of indirect inguinal hernia where the hernia is limited to the inguinal canal.

Indirect inguinal hernia is more common on the right side because of the delay in atrophy of the processus vaginalis after the normal slower descent of the right testis to the scrotum during fetal development.

Related Pearl: Types of indirect inguinal hernia

  • Bubonocele – Hernia limited to the inguinal canal.
  • Funicular – Hernia stops just above the testis.
  • Complete/scrotal – Hernia reaches bottom of scrotum.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with flaccid bullae over the mucosa and skin and oral ulcers. Histopathology shows a suprabasal acantholytic blister with superficial dermal infiltration by lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophils. Direct immunofluorescence for immunoglobulin IgG is as seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Flaccid bullae, oral ulcers, suprabasal acantholytic blisters and fish net appearance on immunofluorescence are characteristic of Pemphigus vulgaris.

The above image shows deposition of immunoglobulin along the plasma membrane of keratinocytes in a reticular or fish net-like pattern accompanied by suprabasalar loss of cell-to-cell adhesion (acantholysis).

Pemphigus is a blistering disorder caused by autoantibodies that result in the dissolution of intercellular attachments within the epidermis and mucosal epithelium.

Variants:

(1) Pemphigus vulgaris

(2) pemphigus vegetans

(3) pemphigus foliaceus: Autoantibodies are against Dsg1 alone, leading to superficial, subcorneal blisters.

(4) pemphigus erythematosus

(5) paraneoplastic pemphigus: in association with various malignancies, most commonly non-Hodgkin lymphoma

Pemphigus vulgaris

  • Most common type of pemphigus
  • Involves the mucosa and skin
  • Autoantibodies against Desmoglein 1 and 3
  • Histology: Suprabasal acantholytic blister leaving behind single layer of intact basal cells: the row of tombstones appearance
  • Direct immunofluorescence: A fish net-like pattern of intercellular IgG deposits.
