questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. The patient is in respiratory distress and his X-ray is shown below. What is the next best step of management?

choices.text: Tube thoracostomy at 5th intercostal space anterior to mid-axillary line
Needle decompression at 5th intercostal space anterior to mid-axillary line
Needle decompression at 5th intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line
Needle decompression at 2nd intercostal space anterior to mid-axillary line

questions.solution:
Immediate management of a tension pneumothorax is done with needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line

Definitive management - tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety.

Triangle of safety:

The boundaries are 

  • Anteriorly - lateral border of the pectoralis major
  • Posteriorly- latissimus dorsi
  • Inferiorly- a line perpendicular to the nipple going to the back

For pediatric patients, needle decompression is done at the midclavicular line in the 2nd intercostal space.

The images below show the triangle of safety and technique of chest drain insertion.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to you with anemia early in her pregnancy. She is 7 weeks pregnant as seen on ultrasound. Her hemoglobin level is 9 g/dL. When should she start taking iron supplements?
questions.solution:
The iron supplements for the 7-week pregnant mother presenting with anemia should be started at 8 to 10 weeks.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention defined anemia in pregnant women using a cut-off value. The pregnant mother is said to be anemic when the level of haemoglobin is less than 11 g/dL in the first and third trimesters and less than 10.5 g/dL in the second trimester.

Anemia in the first trimester is treated by oral iron therapy. According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, pregnant women with mild and moderate anemia are treated with two iron and folic acid tablets. Each tablet contains 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid. These tablets are taken daily and are supplied by the healthcare worker. Hence, in this mother iron supplementation should be started by 8-10 weeks.

Drawbacks of oral therapy are intolerance presenting as epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, constipation, or diarrhea, and unpredictable absorption rate. The improvement in haemoglobin levels is generally evident within 3 weeks of oral iron therapy.Contraindications to oral therapy are intolerance, and severe anemia in advanced pregnancy. In these patients, intravenous iron therapy may be considered.

The best time to start corrective iron therapy in pregnancy depends on the individual patient's needs and the presence of anemia. For most pregnant women without anemia, it is recommended to start iron supplementation between 12-16 weeks of gestation to meet the increased iron demands during pregnancy.If a pregnant woman has anemia, iron supplementation should be started as soon as diagnosed, regardless of the gestational age.

questions.text: While performing the following pediatric emergency procedure being performed on the model of an infant, which of the following indicates a wrong technique?

choices.text: Compression : Breath ratio should ideally be 30:2
Fingers should be lifted off the chest to allow effective recoil between compressions
Efficiency of chest compression should be assessed with brachial pulse periodically
Alternatively, the two thumb technique is equally effective

questions.solution:
The image shows infant CPR. Fingers should not be lifted off the chest between compressions.

Infant CPR:

1. Compression:Breath Ratio:

  • Ideally, there should be 30 chest compressions and 2 breaths in a minute.i.e 100-120 compressions per minute (use 15:2 ratio if second rescuer arrives)

2. Finger Placement:

  • During chest compressions, it's crucial to ensure proper finger placement and technique. The rescuer's fingers or thumbs should remain in contact with the infant's chest throughout compressions and release.
  • Lifting fingers off the chest between compressions can decrease the effectiveness of CPR by not allowing for full chest recoil. Effective recoil is necessary to facilitate venous return and optimize cardiac output.

3. Efficiency Assessment:

  • While performing CPR on an infant, the rescuer should periodically assess the effectiveness of chest compressions. This assessment can be done by checking for the presence of a brachial pulse.
  • If a pulse is palpable, it indicates adequate circulation, and chest compressions should be continued. If no pulse is palpable, CPR should be continued with the appropriate compression-to-breath ratio.

4. Two-Finger Technique vs. Two Thumb Technique:

  • Both the two-finger technique (using two fingers, usually the index and middle fingers) and the two-thumb technique (using both thumbs) are considered effective for performing chest compressions on infants.
  • The choice between these techniques often depends on rescuer preference and comfort. Both techniques aim to achieve adequate compression depth and recoil to effectively circulate blood.

questions.text: A patient was admitted to the ICU 48 hours after the fracture of the femur. The saturation of oxygen in the rebreathing unit was 100% but his SpO2 remained at 60%. The patient is in a state of confusion. Chest radiograph showed lung fields to be clear. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the above clinical scenario is a fat embolism. The presence of respiratory insufficiency and altered mental status following a long bone fracture (fracture of the femur) favors the diagnosis.

Fat embolism syndrome results from the presence of numerous fat emboli within the microcirculation. It most commonly occurs after the fracture of the long bone or pelvis. They present with non-specific symptoms like tachypnea, tachycardia, and fever that manifest within 24- 48 hours after the injury. Damage to the microvasculature of various organs leads to :

  • Mild hypoxia to rapidly progressing respiratory failure.
  • Depression of the central nervous system.
  • Petechial rashes
  • Hemorrhagic lesions of the retina.

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Axillary or subconjunctival petechiae
  • Hypoxemia with PaO2 <60 mmHg, FIO2 < 0.4
  • CNS depression disproportionate to the hypoxemia
  • Pulmonary edema

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia (HR >110 beats per minute)
  • Pyrexia (temp >38.50C)
  • Emboli visible in retina
  • Fat globules in urine
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Unexplanied drop in hematocrit or platelet count 
  • Increased ESR

 At least one major criterion and four minor criteria are required to make a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: The most common pattern of involvement in Pott's spine is
questions.solution:
The most common pattern of involvement in Pott's spine is the paradiscal type.

Pott's spine occurs secondary to a pulmonary or gastrointestinal primary and spreads through the Batson's plexus of veins (paravertebral plexus) and most commonly involves the dorso-lumbar region. 

Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

  • Paradiscal - contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae and the middle intervening disc are affected. This is due to the high oxygen requirements of tubercular bacteria and the corresponding high blood supply in this region by the segmental vessels.
  • Central - the body of the vertebra is involved leading to collapse (causing wedging or concertina collapse) of the affected vertebra. This leads to spinal deformities such as kyphosis and gibbus.
  • Anterior - the anterior part of the body is affected and spreads through the anterior longitudinal ligament.
  • Posterior - the posterior complex (pedicle, lamina, spinous process, and transverse process) is affected.

The image below shows various parts of the vertebra and patterns of involvement in Pott's spine:

Clinical features of spinal tuberculosis:

  • Back pain, stiffness, and reduced movements are the usual early complaints
  • Cautious gait - a person with spinal tuberculosis will walk carefully with short steps to avoid pain resulting from movement
  • Pott's paraplegia
  • Cold abscess
  • Concertina collapse - a type of compression fracture without the involvement of the intervertebral disc
  • Deformity - kyphus and gibbus (gradually increasing prominence).

Images showing concertina collapse and the deformities seen in TB spine.

questions.text: A patient who had undergone a thyroidectomy suddenly develops dyspnea with stridor. On examination, he had tachycardia and hypotension. Management of this case includes all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The above scenario is likely due to the development of a hematoma post-thyroidectomy. Hematoma formation post-thyroidectomy is managed by all the above methods except the administration of propylthiouracil. Propylthiouracil is used for the treatment of thyrotoxic crises.

Hematoma formation post-thyroidectomy occurs due to the slipping of ligatures of the superior thyroid artery, other pedicles, or small veins. This leads to venous edema of the larynx and can cause airway obstruction and respiratory distress.

Clinically, patients will have tachycardia, hypotension, breathlessness, stridor, and respiratory obstruction due to tension hematoma under strap muscles.

It is a life-threatening complication and should be monitored in the first 24 hours after surgery. As first aid, immediate release of sutures including deep fascia has to be done and pressure over the trachea is released. Then the patient is shifted to the operation theatre and under general anesthesia re-exploration is done and bleeders are ligated.

Laryngeal edema may occur due to a hematoma with tension, intubation injury, and surgical trauma. In this condition, along with evacuation of the hematoma, endotracheal intubation is also needed immediately to avoid airway obstruction. If it is impossible to intubate, a needle tracheostomy using a 12-gauge needle (2.3 mm diameter) is done temporarily.

Complications of thyroidectomy:

  • Hemorrhage - most common complication overall
  • Nerve injury 
    • External laryngeal nerve - hoarseness (more common)
    • Recurrent laryngeal nerve - hoarseness if unilateral, life-threatening aspiration and aphonia if bilateral
  • Respiratory obstruction
    • Laryngeal edema - the most common cause of respiratory obstruction
    • Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
    • Laryngomalacia
    • Tension hematoma
  • Hypoparathyroidism - infarction of parathyroids
  • Thyroid storm - inadequately prepared for surgery
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Recurrent thyrotoxicosis
  • Wound infection, stitch granuloma, keloid.

Related Pearl: Blood Supply to the Thyroid Gland

Arterial supply of the thyroid gland

Vessel

Origin

Superior thyroid artery

External carotid artery

Inferior thyroid artery

Thyrocervical trunk (1st part of Subclavian artery)

Arteria thyroidea ima

Brachiocephalic trunk/arch of aorta

Note: Inferior thyroid artery supplies the parathyroid gland

 

Venous drainage of the thyroid gland

Vessel

Origin

Superior and middle thyroid veins

4th vein of Kocher (if present)

Tributary of internal jugular vein

Inferior thyroid vein

Tributary of brachiocephalic vein

questions.text: Identify the fluid shown below.
questions.solution:
The fluid shown in the image is ringer lactate or Hartmann's solution.

Ringer lactate, or Hartmann's solution, is a crystalloid made up of sodium 131 mEq, chloride 112 mEq, potassium 5 mEq, bicarbonate (as lactate) 29 mEq, and 2 mEq of calcium. It is devoid of glucose.

It is useful in the following conditions: 

  • Correction of severe hypovolemia
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Postoperative period, burns, diarrhea
  • Correction of hypokalemia
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis.

It should be avoided in severe shock, liver diseases, vomiting, nasogastric aspiration, and metabolic alkalosis. It cannot be used along with blood transfusion since calcium in the ringer lactate can bind with citrate in the transfused blood leading to clot formation. 

Other options:

Option A: Haemaccel is a colloid and contains 145 mmol of sodium, 6.25 mmol of calcium, and 5.1 mmol of potassium. It is mainly used for rapid volume replacement in circulatory shock, burns, and trauma. These release histamine and hence, H2 blocker has to be supplemented. It is also used in heart-lung machines.

Options C and D: Isolyte P and Isolyte M are crystalloids. Isolyte P is commonly used in fluid therapy for pediatrics. One liter contains 50 grams of glucose, 25 mEq of sodium, 22 mEq of potassium, 3 mEq of magnesium, and 23 mEq of acetate. Hyponatremia, renal failure, hyperkalemia, and hypovolemic shock are some of the contraindications.

Isolyte M is used for maintenance. It mainly contains 50 grams of glucose, 40 mEq sodium, 38 mEq chloride, 35 mEq potassium, 15 mEq phosphate, and 20 mEq acetate. It is useful in correcting hypokalemia in patients with good renal function, and acidosis. It is contraindicated in hyponatremia.

questions.text: Identify the correct statement about the information obtained from the vaccine vial monitor 14 (VVM14) shown in the image below.

choices.text: It takes 14 days for the inner square to become darker than outer circle
It takes 14 days for the inner square and outer circle to reach the same color
The vaccine can be used for 14 days after the inner square and outer circle reach the same color
The vaccine can be used for 14 days after the outer circle color  becomes darker

questions.solution:
The correct statement is option 2.

The given scenario mentions VVM 14 (vaccine vial monitor 14), where 14 indicates the VVM number. It is the time in days for the inner square to reach the color of the outer circle when the vial is exposed to a constant temperature of 37°C. This color change signifies the discard point of the vial.

Vaccine Vial Monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators that are routinely used to monitor vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain. It records cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.

There are currently 4 types of VVMs, they are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccines based on the VVM number. 

  • VVM 30: High Stability
  • VVM 14: Medium Stability
  • VVM 7: Moderate Stability
  • VVM 2: Least Stable

If the color of the inner square is the same or is darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to high temperatures and should be discarded.

Purpose of VVMs:

  • Ensures that vaccines damaged by heat are not administered
  • Decision on which vaccines to be kept after a cold chain break occurs, minimizing unnecessary vaccine wastage
  • Decision on which vaccine is to be used first. Vaccines showing significant heat exposure should be used before those that show lower heat exposure, even if their expiry date is longer

There are two different locations for VVMs :

  • On the label of the vaccine: The vaccine vial, once opened, can be kept for subsequent immunization sessions for up to 28 days, regardless of the formulation of the product
  • In a location other than on the label (e.g., cap or neck of ampoule): The vaccine vial, once opened should be discarded at the end of the immunization session or within six hours of opening, whichever comes first, regardless of the formulation of the product

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: In a patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, what is the finding shown in the image given?
questions.solution:
In a patient with abdominal pain with sterile pyuria, the given image finding points towards a diagnosis of a putty kidney.

The putty kidney is a characteristic finding of genitourinary tuberculosis (TB), specifically renal TB. The given image shows a homogenous and ground glass-like calcification of the kidney appearing like putty.

It is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream and is thus is always a secondary TB. There is either reinfection or reactivation of old TB.

Genitourinary TB is a cause of sterile pyuria. Diagnosis is confirmed with a tuberculin test, or at least 3 consecutive early-morning specimens of urine are examined for acid-fast bacilli. They are stained with a Ziehl–Neelsen stain and subsequently cultured.

CT is the most sensitive modality and is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications. CT urography is done to assess the various stages of renal TB and its manifestations which are as follows:

  • Early: Papillary necrosis
  • Progressive:
    • Multifocal strictures
    • Generalized or focal hydronephrosis
    • Mural thickening and enhancement
    • Poorly enhancing renal parenchyma
  • End-stage:
    • Progressive hydronephrosis
    • Amorphous dystrophic calcification that involves the entire kidney - putty kidney

Treatment involves short-course therapy with antitubercular drugs like pyrazinamide, isoniazid, and rifampicin. Partial nephrectomy, nephrectomy, or reconstructive surgery is often done.

Other options: Nephrocalcinosis is the deposition of calcium in the kidney parenchyma or tubules which is seen in hypercalcemia conditions like hyperparathyroidism. (option B)

Staghorn calculus is found in urinary infection with Proteus, Pseudomonas and Staphylococcus usually, and is not a cause for sterile pyuria. (Option C)

Psoas calcification is a muscle calcification and might be seen developing after acute renal failure and rhabdomyolysis. (Option D)

questions.text: A patient with a history of DVT currently presents with tachypnea and tachycardia. Chest X-ray shows focal oligemia. The ECG is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of pulmonary embolism. ECG shows the S1Q3T3 sign (i.e, an S wave in lead I, a Q wave in lead III, and an inverted T wave in lead III) that is relatively specific but insensitive. The most common sign of pulmonary embolism is tachypnea.

Most common symptom of pulmonary embolism is dyspnea. Most common ECG abnormality in pulmonary embolism is sinus tachycardia.Most common preliminary investigation used is D-dimer.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: A newborn baby weighs 2kg and falls in the small for gestational age in the standard intra-uterine growth curves. Which of the following will give a clue to the cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ponderal index is used to determine the cause of intrauterine growth resitriction in small for gestational age babies.

Ponderal index =  Weight (in g) * 100  / Length (in cm 3) 

  • > 2 signifies symmetric IUGR
  • < 2 signifies asymmetric IUGR
Symmetrical IUGR Asymmetrical IUGR
Entire body appears small Head sparing - Head size normal, rest of the body is small
Insults in 1st trimester Insults in 2nd and 3rd trimester

Fetal factors like chromosomal disorders

and congenital infections

Maternal factors like placental insufficiency

and maternal malnutrition
Poor prognosis Good prognosis

Other options:

Option B - APGAR Score:

  • The APGAR score is a quick assessment tool used to evaluate a newborn's condition immediately after birth. It evaluates Appearance (skin color), Pulse (heart rate), Grimace (reflex irritability), Activity (muscle tone), and Respiration (breathing).
  • While the APGAR score provides valuable information about the newborn's immediate well-being and helps guide resuscitative efforts if necessary, it does not directly provide clues to the cause of being small for gestational age (SGA).

Option C - Ballard Score:

  • The Ballard score is a method used to assess the gestational age of a newborn based on physical and neurological characteristics.
  • It evaluates various parameters such as skin texture, lanugo, ear firmness, breast tissue, genitalia, and neurological maturity.
  • While the Ballard score helps determine the gestational age, it does not directly provide clues to the cause of being SGA.

Option D -  Head Circumference:

  • Head circumference is an important anthropometric measurement used to assess newborn growth and development.
  • It provides valuable information about brain growth and can help identify abnormalities such as microcephaly or macrocephaly.
  • While head circumference is relevant in evaluating newborn growth, it may not directly provide clues to the cause of being SGA.
  • However, abnormalities in head circumference may indicate underlying conditions affecting growth and development.

questions.text: A young man comes to the urology department with a chronic history of deformity of the penis, erectile dysfunction, and pain on erection.  On examination, there were palpable penile plaques and penile ultrasound showed a thickened area of tissue around tunica albuginea. He has been using the device shown below but is now seeking a permanent solution. What surgical procedure you would recommend for him?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is suffering from Peyronie’s disease. The image shows the traction device/ extender used to treat excessive penile curvature. The most common surgical procedure used in Peyronie’s disease is Nesbit's procedure.

Peyronie's disease is characterized by penile deformity, palpable penile plaques, erectile dysfunction, and pain on erection. It causes the penis to bend, usually towards the side of the plaque. It can be associated with Dupuytren's contracture as a part of the Galezia triad (Dupuytren's contracture, retroperitoneal fibrosis, Peyronie's disease).

Some cases may resolve spontaneously. If not, conservative measures such as oral tamoxifen, vitamin E, terfenadine, intralesional verapamil, etc. can be attempted. Intralesional collagenase has also been used. Penile extenders/ traction devices such as the devices shown in the above image have also been used. However, if none of these methods are effective, surgical management can be tried using Nesbit's procedure.

Nesbit's procedure is indicated when all other interventions have failed and the patient is experiencing difficulties in their sexual and personal life due to this condition. The procedure is started by creating an artificial erection by injecting normal saline. Following this, an elliptical excision is done on the convex side of the penis (opposite to the thickened plaque). The width of the excised tissue depends on the degree of penile deformity. The side with the plaque is left as it is. 

The images attached below depict the pathology in Peyronie's disease and the ultrasound finding observed in the disease-

Other options-

Options (A) and (B): Lord’s operation and Jaboulay’s procedure are surgery performed for hydrocoele.

Option (D): Anderson-Hynes operation is a pyeloplasty procedure performed for hydronephrosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida has come for an antenatal ultrasound examination. The sonographic image appears as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the lemon sign, which is seen in spina bifida.

Spina bifida is the common open neural tube defect associated with hydrocephalus and Arnold-Chiari II malformation. It is the most common open neural tube disorder.

Spina bifida is characterized by a cleft in the vertebral column with a corresponding defect in the skin so that the meninges and spinal cord are exposed.

The lemon sign is related to changes in the configuration of the fetal frontal bone that loses convexity, becoming concave or linear at ultrasonography, and can be found during the first six months of gestation.

The banana sign is another sign that is seen in spina bifida associated with Arnold-Chiari II. There is herniation of the brainstem and cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, with the cerebellum surrounding the brainstem with a curved shape of a banana.

Other options:

Option B: Anencephaly is characterized by an open defect in the calvaria and skin, such that the cranial neural tube is exposed. It is a severe defect and is not compatible with survival. Frog eye sign is seen in USG. Prominent orbits (arrows) and an absence of cerebral tissue more cranially are seen.

Option C: Holoprosencephaly is a rare congenital brain malformation resulting from incomplete separation of the two hemispheres. On antenatal ultrasound there may be also evidence of polyhydramnios and ultrasound may also show a snake under the skull sign.

Option D: Omphalocele is a midline anterior abdominal wall defect through which the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel may herniate. The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac. Given below is an ultrasound image of the fetus suggestive of an omphalocele (asterix).

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents with right hemisensory loss followed by agonizing, burning pain in the affected regions. The pain responds poorly to analgesics. These features are classically seen in _______.
questions.solution:
Hemisensory loss and severe burning pain in the affected regions is classically seen in Dejerine Roussy syndrome aka Thalamic pain syndrome.

The P1 segment of the posterior cerebral artery extends from the basilar bifurcation to the junction with the posterior communicating artery. Dejerine- Roussy syndrome occurs due to occlusion of the thalamic and thalamogeniculate branches arising from the P1 segment resulting in contralateral hemisensory loss and severe burning pain in the affected regions.

This pain responds poorly to analgesics. Anticonvulsants such as carbamazepine or gabapentin or tricyclic antidepressants may be beneficial.

questions.text: You are an intern asked to catheterize a patient using a 16F Foley's catheter. You are unable to catheterize the patient and decide to use a slightly smaller catheter. The ward sister gives you the following four fresh catheters. Which one would you choose instead?
questions.solution:
The Foley's catheter having a green coloured ring in the ballon port is of size 14 F. If there is difficulty in catheterization, then a lower French number should be preferred.

Related Pearl: Foley's catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the external circumference in millimetres. French size divided by 3 will give the outer diameter of the catheter. 

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 3 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 3 mm and a diameter of 1 mm. 

Note:

Colour of the foleys is the colour at the baloon port as shown in the figure below
